Because “at will” employment states have higher attrition rates
Falsely called “at will,” and misappropriated as a line of defense for discrimination, this important and valuable business process goes by the name of probation period.
One benefit of the probation period is it allows you to hire top talent who may not be a “fit” for your company. As a bonus, probation periods also work for existing employees who may need to transition to different responsibilities. The probabilities of success with these “integrated” personnel are higher due to employee familiarity with your company, product, services and operational philosophies.
Of course, probationary periods aren’t a panacea and you can only succeed if you take the time to set clear and attainable objectives for the “probie.” Further, you have to make sure your HR department and middle management is onboard. Here’s a quick list of what you should consider in creating and managing your probation period.
Get HR involved – create a short but informative on-boarding training manual that will be reviewed and signed by the manager of the new hire during the employee orientation. The agreement serves as the contract between your company and the new employee, so it’s important to use this period to give your employee the basics (dress codes, IT protocols, time cards, company policies, etc.) and the broader vision of the company. HR should also be in charge of recruiting the new employees and use this period as a way to start the retention process.

Here ’ s a swift list of what you should consider in establishing and controlling your probation term .Get HR involved – produce a brief but informative on - boarding training manual that will be evaluated and signed by the manager of the new hiring during the worker orientation . The agreement acts as the deal between your firm and the new employee , so it ’ s important to use this period to give your customer the basics ( clothes codes , IT procedures , time cards , company guidelines , etc . )and the broader vision of the company . HR should also be in charge of recruiting the new workers and use this period as a way to start the retention cycle .
text3: "Probation period" is a crucial business process often mislabeled as "at will" employment, leading to higher turnover rates in those states. The probation period allows you to bring in top talent who may not initially seem like a good fit for your company. In addition to new hires, probation periods can also benefit current employees needing to switch roles. Having employees who are already familiar with your company, products, services, and operational philosophies increases the likelihood of success. However, setting clear and achievable goals for probationary employees is essential for success. Additionally, it is important to ensure that both your HR department and middle management are in agreement. Here is a quick checklist for establishing and managing your probation period. HR should create a concise onboarding training manual for new hires to be reviewed and signed by their manager during orientation. During the probation period, it is crucial to provide new employees with essential information such as dress codes, IT procedures, time cards, and company guidelines. the company's overall goals and objectives. It is HR's responsibility to recruit new employees and utilize the probation period to kickstart the retention process.

Some people use the words “illegal” and “unlawful” interchangeably, but they are not identical. The words denote legally distinct categories. For example, a person can commit “unlawful conduct” that does not make the person liable to criminal punishment, whereas the commission of “illegal conduct” does expose the person to criminal punishment. (See People v. Garcia (1996) 44 Cal.App.4th 97, 109–110, [52 Cal.Rptr.2d 50]; People v. Baker (2000) 79 Cal.App.4th 854, 861, [94 Cal.Rptr.2d 637].)
Fornication is unlawful, but it is not illegal, and it cannot serve as the basis for a criminal prosecution. (See In re K.C. (1993) 12 Cal.App.4th 1579, 1582, [16 Cal.Rptr.2d 184] [discussing People v. Porter (1969) 274 Cal.App.2d 750, [80 Cal.Rptr. 216] and stating that “fornication may have been unlawful but not illegal conduct within the meaning of the Penal Code”]; accord People v. Baker, supra, 79 Cal.App.4th at p.

You can. It's just hard to do.
Many of the famous statements of philosophy, science, or religion have been expressions of an ontological position, one in which the objective reality of some particular concept is declared. These statements often take the form of absolutes, which are statements that something is, or is not. They assert an ontological position. "God is" (Boethius) or "The King is dead" (Oliver Cromwell) are examples of declarative absolutes. More complex examples include Descartes' "cogito ergo sum" ("I think therefore I am") or Saint Anselm's famous ontological proof of the existence of God.
What does it mean to make such statements? As with the better-known tautologies (statements in which the subject and predicate are identical, such as "the president is president"), one is usually interested not in the abstract validity of the statement but rather the truth or falsity of the subject, which is presented as a question.
For example, when I tell someone that "Mondavi is the best wine," they may respond, "No, Mondavi is not the best wine. It is too heavy, too oaky, too aggressive, and too expensive." They have successfully argued against the truth of my statement, because my statement was true only in that one wine is superior to any other particular wine.

These statements often take the form of absolutes , which are statements that things is , or is not .They claim an ontological stance . " God is " ( Boethius ) or " The King is dead " ( Oliver Cromwell ) are examples of declarative absolutes .More complex examples include Descartes ' " cogito ergo sum " ( " I believe consequently I am " ) or Saint Anselm ' s famous ontological confirmation of the existence of God . What does it mean to make such statements ?As with the better - recognized tautologies ( statements in which the subject and predicate are identical , such as " the president is president " ) , one is usually interested not in the abstract validity of the statement but rather the truth or falsity of the subject , which is given as a question . For instance , when I say someone that " Mondavi is the best wine , " they may respond , " No , Mondavi is not the best wine .It is too heavy , too oaky , too aggressive , and too costly . " They have successfully defended against the truth of my statement , because my statement was true only in that one wine is superior to any other specific wine .
text3: It is possible. It's difficult to accomplish. Famous statements in philosophy, science, or religion often assert the objective truth of a particular concept from an ontological perspective. These statements typically assert absolute truths about the existence or non-existence of things, taking a stance from an ontological perspective. Examples of declarative absolutes include statements like "God is" (Boethius) or "The King is dead" (Oliver Cromwell). Complicated instances include Descartes' "I think, therefore I am" or Saint Anselm's well-known argument for the existence of God. What is the significance of making such declarations? Similar to well-known tautologies, the focus is typically on determining the truth or falsity of the subject rather than the abstract validity of the statement itself. If I were to claim that "Mondavi is the best wine," someone might argue that it is not the best due to being heavy, oaky, aggressive, and expensive. They have effectively refuted my statement by pointing out that it was only true in the sense that one wine is better than a specific other wine.

text1:
The law of the United States and many other countries protects the rights of those who are accused of crimes. It is not the job of the defense lawyer to decide whether a person is guilty or not. The defense lawyer has an ethical duty to ensure that the person receives a fair trial, and is entitled to review evidence the prosecution wants to introduce at trial. The defense lawyer also has an ethical duty to ensure that the prosecution does not commit errors during the case that may harm the person’s rights.
Fighting the charges against a person accused of committing a crime can be difficult because the person is often facing a prosecutor who works for the government, who has more money to pay for witnesses and experts, and who has a higher level of experience. However, it is not fair to assume that a person who is in court is guilty, and people accused of crimes should be treated fairly by the justice system.
text2: The law of the United States and many other countries protects the rights of those who are accused of offences . It is not the job of the defense attorney to decision whether a person is innocent or not .The defense attorney has an ethical obligation to ensure that the person gets a fair prosecution , and is entitled to review evidence the prosecution wants to introduce at trial . The defense attorney also has an ethical obligation to ensure that the prosecution does not commit errors during the case that might impact the person ’ s rights .Fighting the allegations against a person accused of committing a crime can be problematic because the person is often facing a prosecutor who works for the government , who has more funds to pay for testimony and experts , and who has a higher level of experience . However , it is not fair to assume that a person who is in court is innocent , and people convicted of offences should be treated properly by the justice system .
text3: The rights of individuals accused of crimes are protected by the law in the United States and numerous other countries. The defense attorney's role is to ensure a fair trial for the accused and review evidence presented by the prosecution. The defense attorney must also make sure that the prosecution does not make any mistakes that could harm the rights of the accused individual. It is unjust to automatically assume innocence for individuals in court, and those convicted of crimes deserve proper treatment within the justice system.

- Great Question. This takes a while to explain so please be patient.
Technically, ego death is when you feel you no longer have a coherent sense of self and your brain goes a bit haywire. It may be described as having a "melt down" or an "nervous breakdown." It is often the result of intense feelings of guilt, anxiety, fear, shame, or anger. Basically, the ego reacts to a sense of impending annihilation, which feels like death.
Psychiatrist Bill Manahan defines the ego as the "self-esteem system" of the brain and explains that, when confronted with stressful and traumatic events, the ego seeks to protect itself and will "get you to change to avoid the bad feelings." The ego survives by distorting the truth and will manufacture lies and distortions of reality to make it work.
When the ego's lies and distortions of reality become too big, a type of "identity crisis" occurs and the ego's identity ceases to exist. In this state, one experiences a loss of a sense of self.
In the great scheme of things, it doesn't really matter if the experience is temporary or permanent. What does matter is the perspective taken of the experience: In the face of annihilation, can we respond with compassion and curiosity?
There are certain conditions which tend to bring on ego death. I would say that psychedelic medicines are the first in line for ego death.

Basically , the ego reacts to a sense of inevitable annihilation , which feels like death .Psychiatrist Bill Manahan identifies the ego as the " self - esteem system " of the brain and explains that , when encountered with stressful and traumatic events , the ego seeks to shield itself and will " get you to shift to escape the good emotion . " The ego survives by distorting the facts and will create lying and distortions of reality to make it work .When the ego ' s lies and distortions of reality become too big , a kind of " identity situation " happens and the ego ' s identity ceases to exist . What does matter is the viewpoint taken of the experience : In the face of annihilation , can we reply with compassion and curiosity ?There are certain conditions which tend to bring on ego suicide . I would argue that psychedelic substances are the first in line for ego murder .
text3: Excellent inquiry. Explaining ego suicide may take some time, so please be patient as it involves losing a clear sense of self and experiencing mental chaos. It could be likened to a meltdown or a nervous breakdown. Ego suicide is frequently caused by intense emotions such as guilt, anxiety, worry, or rage. The ego responds to a feeling of unavoidable destruction, which is akin to death. Bill Manahan describes the ego as the brain's self-esteem system that tries to protect itself by prompting a shift away from positive emotions during stressful situations. The ego distorts reality and resorts to lying in order to survive. When the ego's lies and distortions become overwhelming, it leads to a loss of identity. During this state, an individual loses their sense of identity. In the grand scheme of things, the permanence of the experience is not significant. The important thing is how we choose to approach the experience: Can we respond with compassion and curiosity in the face of annihilation? Specific circumstances can trigger ego suicide. Psychedelic substances are often considered the primary catalyst for ego suicide.

text1: Federal Judge is a federal employee, hired to interpret, protect and uphold the Constitution of the United States and laws that derive from it. This includes both the laws that have been passed by the Federal government and laws that are violations of the Constitution of the United States. Of course a state has the right to strike down the federal judge decision, but what happens then? The State Supreme Court that will hear the case is made up of the Federal Judge.

text1:
A jury in Kenosha, Wisconsin, found the 18-year-old not guilty on all counts after deliberating for nearly 3 days. Rittenhouse faced charges of first-degree intentional homicide and two counts of first-degree reckless homicide.
Before the verdict was read, about 20 state troopers were stationed in the basement of the courthouse as a precaution against potential violence. In the end, no major protests or violence occurred.
The shooting happened on Aug. 25, 2020, at a chaotic protest against police brutality in Kenosha, Wisconsin. On the evening of that day, police shot Jacob Blake, a Black man, in the back, leaving him paralyzed from the waist down. Rittenhouse was 17 at the time, but authorities in Wisconsin allow 17-year-olds to be tried as adults.
It was later learned that Rittenhouse traveled to Kenosha from his home in Antioch, Illinois, about 25 miles (40 km) away.
Q: What were the charges?
A: The jury found Rittenhouse not guilty on all counts.
There were two counts of first-degree intentional homicide. The first stemmed from the shooting death of 36-year-old Joseph Rosenbaum and the second from the death of 26-year-old Anthony Huber. Both men were unarmed when they were shot.

In the end , no major demonstrations or violence occurred .The shot happened on Aug . 25 , 2020 , at a chaotic demonstration against police violence in Kenosha , Wisconsin . On the night of that week , authorities shot Jacob Blake , a Black man , in the back , left him paralyzed from the waist down .Rittenhouse was 17 at the time , but authorities in Wisconsin allow 17 - year - olds to be tried as adults . It was later realized that Rittenhouse went to Kenosha from his home in Antioch , Illinois , about 25 miles ( 40 km ) distant .Q : What were the allegations ? A : The jury found Rittenhouse not guilty on all counts .There were two counts of first - degree intentional murder . The first stemmed from the shot death of 36 - month - old Joseph Rosenbaum and the second from the death of 26 - month - old Anthony Huber .Both men were unarmed when they were shot.

The incident took place in August. In August 2020, there was a chaotic protest against police violence in Kenosha, Wisconsin. During that week, Jacob Blake, a Black man, was shot in the back by authorities, resulting in him being paralyzed from the waist down. Although Rittenhouse was 17 years old at the time, Wisconsin law allows 17-year-olds to be tried as adults. Rittenhouse was found to have traveled from his home in Antioch, Illinois, which is approximately 25 miles away from Kenosha. What charges were brought against him? Rittenhouse was acquitted of all charges, including two counts of first-degree intentional murder. The charges were related to the deaths of Joseph Rosenbaum and Anthony Huber, who were both unarmed when they were shot.

In 2015, the President approved the Congressional spending bill which established a “rewards program,” authorizing the Secretary of Defense to pay up to $25 million for information regarding high-value targets.
Q: Can I still get the $25 million reward?
A: Yes, only for US citizens and lawful permanent residents. If you are not a US citizen or permanent resident, you may still report information, however, there are no longer rewards for individuals.
Q: How do I report information?
A: Information regarding al-Qaeda, ISIS, and other al-Qaeda aligned affiliates, and certain leadership of Iranian-backed groups can be reported at this link: https://www.dni.gov/file-under-threat. You must complete a report which will be sent to the Department of Defense and the Department of State for review.
Q: Who reviews the reported information?
A: The Departments of State and Defense review the reported information. Depending on the information reported, the Department of Treasury and Intelligence Community may also review.
Q: I have reported information, what happens next?
A: You will receive a confirmation email confirming receipt of your report.
Q: I still have questions and/or concerns, who can I talk to?
A: You can contact the Rewards Office at https://www.dni.gov/rewarg
Q: Do I have to do anything to preserve information?

text1:
The word “sanction” comes from Latin: sancire, which means to make holy, or to designate.
That explains the religious wars of Europe, and the Spanish Inquisition.
If one nation designates another nation as holy, then it becomes a crime to have any dealings with the other nation, especially if you are Roman Catholic.
All manner of evil consequences can follow, such as war, or the forced conversion to Christianity of the Catholics in Northern Ireland.
Any way, back to the question: why does the US impose sanctions on other nations?
Because they are protecting themselves.

All sort of bad consequences can follow , such as war , or the forced conversion to Christianity of the Catholics in Northern Ireland .Any way , back to the question : why does the US enforce sanctions on other countries ? Because they are guarding themselves .
text3: The word "sanction" comes from the Latin word "sancire," which means to make holy or designate. This sheds light on the religious conflicts in Europe and the Spanish Inquisition. If one country designates another as holy, it is considered a crime to have any interactions with that nation, especially if you are Roman Catholic. Various negative outcomes may result, including warfare or the coerced conversion of Catholics in Northern Ireland to Christianity. However, returning to the original question: why does the US impose sanctions on other nations? They are protecting themselves.

text1:
Prosecutors brought a murder charge because Rittenhouse is alleged to have shot two men who were fleeing from him and who could not have posed a threat at the time, a legal analysis of the case shows.
When Kyle Rittenhouse fatally shot two people during a riot in Kenosha, Wis., in 2020, it’s possible he could have been charged with manslaughter, instead of murder.
The teenager, who was in court in Wisconsin on Monday to face charges, could still be convicted of homicide even if his lawyer succeeds in persuading jurors that he was acting in self-defense at the time. The question now is the severity of the charge: murder or manslaughter.
“You have a person who shot someone who was fleeing,” said Josh Margolis, a defense lawyer and lecturer at the Northwestern University law school. “If that person didn’t have a gun, he would probably be convicted of manslaughter.”
Rittenhouse, 18, is charged with first-degree intentional homicide in the death of Anthony Huber, a 26-year-old protester who had been swinging a skateboard at Rittenhouse, a former member of a police cadet program in the suburbs of Chicago. He is also charged with attempted first-degree intentional homicide in the shooting of Joseph Rosenbaum, a 36-year-old who chased Rittenhouse on the night of the Aug. 25, 2020, protest. Rittenhouse shot him after he appeared to throw a plastic bag at him.
text2: Prosecutors brought a homicide charge because Rittenhouse is accused to have shooting two men who were fleeing from him and who might not have posing a danger at the time , a legal analysis of the case shows . When Kyle Rittenhouse fatally shot two people during a riot in Kenosha , Wis . , in 2020 , it ’ s possible he possible have been charged with manslaughter , rather of murder .The teenager , who was in court in Wisconsin on Monday to facing charges , might still be convicted of murder even if his lawyer succeeds in persuading jurors that he was acting in self - defense at the time . The question now is the severity of the charge : homicide or manslaughter .“ You have a person who shot people who was escaping , ” says Josh Margolis , a defense attorney and lecturer at the Northwestern University law school . “ If that someone didn ’ t have a gun , he would probably be convicted of manslaughter . ” Rittenhouse , 18 , is charged with first - degree intentional murder in the death of Anthony Huber , a 26 - month - old protester who had been swinging a skateboard at Rittenhouse , a retired member of a police cadet program in the suburbs of Chicago .He is also arrested with attempted first - degree intentional murder in the shot of Joseph Rosenbaum , a 36 - year - old who chased Rittenhouse on the night of the Aug . 25 , 2020 , protest . Rittenhouse shot him after he appeared to toss a plastic bag at him .
text3: Prosecutors charged Rittenhouse with homicide for allegedly shooting two men who were running away from him and may not have been posing a threat at the time, according to a legal analysis. Kyle Rittenhouse may face manslaughter charges instead of murder for fatally shooting two people during a riot in Kenosha, Wisconsin in 2020. He could still be convicted of murder even if his self-defense argument is successful in court. The issue at hand is whether Kyle Rittenhouse will be charged with homicide or manslaughter. Josh Margolis, a defense attorney and lecturer at Northwestern University law school, stated that the individual in question shot individuals who were trying to flee. Without a gun, the individual would likely be found guilty of manslaughter. Rittenhouse, 18, faces charges of first-degree intentional murder for the death of Anthony Huber and attempted first-degree intentional murder for shooting Joseph Rosenbaum. Protests occurred in Kenosha, Wisconsin on August 25, 2020. Rittenhouse fired at him after he seemed to throw a plastic bag in his direction.

Q: Do you believe there are other people with autism like yourself who have legal abilities? Can you be a trial lawyer with autism?
A: Yes. It was difficult for me to practice as a lawyer for the first few years. The reason why is, most people don’t realize it, but lawyers do most of their job sitting in a room alone with a pad and a pen and a stack of books. They’re not arguing with opposing counsel. I’m certainly not the only lawyer who’s sitting in a room alone with a stack of books. There are other lawyers out there who have other different challenges. Some lawyers have dyslexia. They didn’t have the advantages I had in school. They might struggle in a different way but that doesn’t make them less capable of practising law than somebody who doesn’t have a disability.
It was just a matter of adapting and becoming good at the things I’m good at. That takes time and there were a lot of learning experiences along the way.

text1:
First, let's acknowledge that the small interfering RNAs in Ingrezza -- and for that matter, the drugs in our "niratenib, maribavir, and pemigatinib" trio -- are biological compounds, and biological compounds are much harder to study than small molecules. Nevertheless, here is the back story.
Ingrezza is not an actual drug but a combination of three active ingredients, each an individual compound.
The first ingredient is a small molecule known as valbenazine, which has been around for a while and has some antipsychotic properties. (Valbenazine itself is not approved in the United States, but it is available in Europe.) The other two are RNA-based drugs, which were only recently discovered, and the science behind how they work is far from clear.
The mystery began with the realization that about one-third of patients with Tourette's do not respond to standard therapy, while those who do respond respond at highly variable rates. Researchers have theorized that something in these patients' genomes prevents them from responding, but no specific genetic cause for nonresponse has been found.
But the patient group that most needs new therapy is that who've been unsuccessfully treated with traditional Tourette's medications for six months or more. So researchers tried a "one size fits all" approach and focused on that group.
Using this methodology, researchers developed a drug made from three small interfering RNAs.
text2: First , let ' s recognize that the small interfering RNAs in Ingrezza - - and for that matter , the drugs in our " niratenib , maribavir , and pemigatinib " duo - - are biological compounds , and biological compounds are greatly harder to study than large molecules . Nevertheless , here is the back story .Ingrezza is not an actual drug but a combination of three active components , each an individual compound . The first ingredient is a small molecule known as valbenazine , which has been around for a while and has some antipsychotic qualities .( Valbenazine itself is not approved in the United States , but it is available in Europe . ) The other two are RNA - based drugs , which were only lately discovered , and the science behind how they work is far from clear .The mystery began with the realization that about one - quarter of people with Tourette ' s do not react to standard medication , while those who do react react at highly varying rates . Researchers have theorized that something in these patients ' genomes prevents them from responding , but no specific genetic cause for nonresponse has been shown .But the patient group that most needs new therapy is that who ' ve been unsuccessfully treated with typical Tourette ' s treatments for six months or more . So researchers tried a " one size fits all " strategy and centered on that group .Using this methodology , researchers produced a drug made from three small interfering RNAs .
text3: Initially, it is important to acknowledge that small interfering RNAs in Ingrezza, as well as the drugs in our "niratenib, maribavir, and pemigatinib" combination, are biological compounds, which are more challenging to study compared to large molecules. However, it is worth noting that Ingrezza is not a single drug, but rather a combination of three separate active compounds. The initial component is valbenazine, a long-standing small molecule with some antipsychotic properties. Valbenazine is not approved for use in the United States, but it can be found in Europe. The two remaining drugs are RNA-based and have been recently identified, with the mechanisms of action still not well understood. This uncertainty arose from the observation that a significant portion of individuals with Tourette's syndrome do not respond to traditional medications, and those who do respond do so at different rates. Researchers believe that there may be a genetic factor preventing some patients from responding to treatment, but a specific genetic cause for nonresponse has not been identified. Patients who have not responded to traditional Tourette's treatments for at least six months are the group most in need of new therapy. Researchers focused on a specific group of patients who have not responded to traditional Tourette's treatments for at least six months. Researchers created a drug using three small interfering RNAs through this approach.

text1:
Why do murderers shoot people at all?
We can’t possibly know that for sure, but the most commonly used guns in America are semi-automatic weapons, capable of firing a dozen rounds in a single pull of the trigger. If we want to protect people, it makes sense to get rid of those.
The rationale here is that it is too much trouble for people to take these kinds of guns apart and get rid of each part separately. I am not buying that excuse. If there was ever a person who felt compelled to remove a firearm from their family and eliminate it from their possession, they would probably not find it too much trouble to get rid of each part of a gun in a different location.
Another argument against taking apart guns to prevent them from being used in a crime is that it’s difficult to track and trace individual parts. I don’t understand why this is such a problem. A person who purchases a firearm has to fill out a form that includes a name, address, and other identifying information. Does the fact that they now have a gun made up of a barrel, a trigger, a trigger guard, a firing mechanism, and so on mean that this tracing can’t take place? Of course it can. There are now multiple pieces of a gun and more information to work with.
There are other arguments made against this approach to gun control, including that a murderer could simply take a different gun to a crime scene and make things just as difficult.

text1:
Jury trials, which are guaranteed by the Constitution, are generally considered the ultimate form of due process. It's a tradition that goes back a long way, originating in England more than a thousand years ago.
In a jury trial, jurors who aren't attorneys decide the facts of a case based on what's presented by the prosecution and defense. That's why it's important that both sides have sufficient time to make their best arguments.
The prosecution bears the burden of proving the accused guilty beyond a reasonable doubt. Even if jurors are satisfied of the defendant's guilt, they're still permitted to acquit the defendant if they can't be convinced beyond a reasonable doubt.
At the conclusion of a jury trial, jurors must adhere to the law as instructed by the judge in a process called "jury nullification." This is why it's important that judges carefully instruct jurors on the law and their responsibilities as jurors.
Suppose, for example, that a police officer abused his power and charged a person with a crime that, based on the evidence, doesn't exist. It's still the job of the jury to decide whether or not the accused person committed a crime.
Jury nullification is the principle that jurors can and must acquit defendants who violate the law, but whose conduct is still considered reasonable and morally correct by the jury.

That ' s why it ' s important that both sides have sufficient time to make their best arguments .The prosecution carries the burden of finding the accused guilty beyond a reasonable doubt . Even if jurors are satisfied of the defendant ' s guilt , they ' re still permitted to acquit the defendant if they can ' t be persuaded beyond a reasonable doubt .At the conclusion of a jury prosecution , jurors may adhere to the law as instructed by the judge in a process called " jury nullification . " This is why it ' s important that courts thoroughly instruct jurors on the law and their responsibilities as jurors .Suppose , for example , that a police officer abused his authority and convicted a person with a crime that , based on the proof , doesn ' t exist . It ' s still the job of the jury to choose whether or not the accused person committed a crime .Jury nullification is the principle that jurors can and must acquit defendants who breach the law , but whose conduct is still deemed reasonable and morally correct by the jury .
text3: Jury trials, ensured by the Constitution, are generally seen as the highest level of due process. This tradition has roots that date back over a thousand years to England. In a jury trial, the jurors, not lawyers, determine the facts of a case based on evidence presented by both sides. It is crucial for both sides to have adequate time to present their strongest arguments, with the prosecution having the responsibility of proving the accused guilty beyond a reasonable doubt. Jurors can still acquit the defendant if they have doubts about guilt, even if they believe the defendant is guilty. At the end of a jury trial, jurors may choose to disregard the law as directed by the judge, known as "jury nullification." Jury nullification allows jurors to disregard the law as instructed by the judge. Courts must provide jurors with clear instructions on the law and their duties, as demonstrated by a scenario where a police officer wrongly accuses someone of a crime that cannot be proven. The jury still has the responsibility of determining the guilt of the accused individual. Jury nullification allows jurors to acquit defendants who have broken the law but are still considered morally justified by the jury.

Jury nullification means that a juror can ignore the law as told by the judge and based on his/her conscience, vote “not guilty” in a case in which the law is clearly violated. Examples of this could be in cases where prosecutors are abusing their power or when individuals are victimized for their political beliefs, race, or because of fear. While jury nullification was once not allowed, it is now widely allowed and can happen anywhere.
While no one wants to go to prison, it is worse to go for the wrong reason. It is a worse thing to do, but a lot better to go to prison for doing what you believe in than for something you did not do.
In the case of Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, 558 U.S. 310 (2010), The Supreme Court ruled that private groups or corporations, such as corporations themselves or non-profits, may spend an unlimited amount of money on political campaign activities, such as political endorsements or running attack ads for candidates.
To do this they would normally have to be registered with the government as a political action committee, but in Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission they ruled that the First Amendment of the US Constitution gives individuals and groups the right to spend whatever they want on their own political speech without being regulated by the government.
To put it in simple terms, it makes it very easy to spend a lot of money on political campaigns.

text1:
An unbroken jury may be hung if they are unable to reach a unanimous verdict. After the jury has been deliberating for at least 2 hours, the Court may ask if they have reached a unanimous decision. If they respond with anything other than “unanimously,” the Court will excuse them and call for a mistrial. The case will be dismissed, and the client will have to hire another attorney and pay for another trial. You must make sure you do not face a hung jury!
Q: What is a bench trial?
A: If you have an excellent case and do not want a jury, you may wish to request a bench trial. A bench trial is just a trial between the attorney and the Judge. A bench trial gives you a better opportunity to prevail, since you will be telling your story to a person you know. A person you know, and who has actually been on the bench for years, listening to a wide range of cases. A person who is completely familiar with the law. If you ask for a bench trial, and the Judge agrees, you will not have a jury in your case. However, this is a risk because the Judge can throw out your case without a jury and you will not get a “hung jury” (this is discussed above). You also will not get an advantage from the “jury instructions” that usually help juries to reach a verdict.

text1:
The British banned handguns in 1997 after the Dunblane school shooting in 1996. A gunman walked into the school and started shooting, killing 16 children and their teacher. The killer then turned the gun on himself.
As you may be aware, the school in Dunblane was the first elementary school in the UK to institute a zero-tolerance policy regarding firearms. This lead to a very firm stance against gun control. In 1997, the government enacted a total ban on handguns, which didn't have a bearing on the law because the school shooting didn't involve a handgun. The government also enacted other gun control measures, which haven't had a measurable effect on gun crime. The police have been given a bigger role in firearm licensing. Since 1997, there have been 73 gun crimes that have led to murder, compared to 19 before the 1997 law was put into effect.
The public has reacted favorably to the new gun control measures, but there is some doubt as to whether or not the guns could've been used by the killer to break into the school in 1996. Also, there were several lawsuits brought against the government by gun enthusiasts and dealers, but they were thrown out of court.

text1:
To be truthful, I’ve never thought about the issue you’re asking about. A lot of human behavior seems completely irrational and contradictory. For example, people sometimes will risk their lives for a person they don’t know or even love. This would seem irrational if life is the most valuable thing, yet risk your life for a loved one and this is not considered irrational.
Also, throughout history there have been people who have thought that war was immoral or at least that it was a choice to be avoided, such as Christ, Gandhi, and Martin Luther King, Jr. But there have been others who have thought war is inevitable and thus not an ethical issue, such as Augustine, Aquinas, and Thomas Hobbes. The world has mostly accepted the views of the second group.
And this is only part of the answer to your question. After people have died, it is true that murder is considered one of the worst things, but what about the people who haven’t died, the people who come back after the war? How do we feel about the guy who gets shot and his brother who was on the other side? In ancient Greece, the person who died was put in the class of heroes, while the man who was spared was thought of as less of a man. And he usually didn’t get any medals, at least at first.
So this is a complex and challenging question that I hope someone smarter than I can tackle.

The media often focuses on the most gruesome murders and is skewed to be anti-death penalty.
Pleading guilty and staying in prison for life isn’t necessarily more comfortable than death row. While the conditions may be slightly better, there are still the long-term impacts. One of the most horrific experiences an inmate on death row can experience is watching friends and loved ones getting executed. Being on death row for an extended amount of time can be debilitating and cause an inmate to lose the will to live. Also, a murderer will lose whatever support they had from family and friends once they become known to the public as a murderer. There is a great risk to family and friends if they choose to stay in prison. They will have to relocate, change their names, and work hard to build new lives.
Finally, why would a murderer want to stay alive in prison and watch as the world passes by them? In jail, a murderer has the opportunity to have sex with anyone who is willing, which is sometimes extremely easy. Many murderers have children in prison because they don’t have to worry about protection or STDs.

text1:
The principles in the two sides of this statement are quite different. With "guilty until proven innocent," a defendant is considered guilty by society until he or she proves otherwise. By contrast, in our system, the burden of proof is on the government. To use our familiar metaphors, the presumption of innocence shifts the burden of proof to the prosecution; the presumption of guilt is the opposite.
While the presumption of innocence serves a number of functions, its primary purpose is to recognize and minimize the inherent difficulty of proving someone innocent. You're presumed innocent until proven guilty. The prosecution, by contrast, does not have to prove you innocent at all -- they have the responsibility to prove you guilty beyond a reasonable doubt.
It's important to note, too, that the term "innocent" has a technical meaning in the criminal justice system, and that meaning has little to do with morality. Legally, to be "innocent" simply means that the prosecution has not proven your guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. Being innocent, legally, is therefore much more difficult to prove than being guilty. Under the legal definition, the defendant doesn't have to do anything. By contrast, the prosecution must prove their case and establish all of the elements of a crime beyond a reasonable doubt.
To be guilty, legally, means that the prosecution has proven your guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. This is a lower threshold than the innocent burden of proof.

You ' re presumed innocent until proven guilty .The prosecution , by contrast , does not have to prove you innocent at all - - they have the responsibility to find you guilty beyond a reasonable doubt . It ' s important to note , too , that the term " innocent " has a technical meaning in the criminal judicial structure , and that meaning has little to do with morality .Legally , to be " innocent " merely implies that the prosecution has not proven your guilt beyond a rational doubt . Being innocent , legally , is consequently much more hard to prove than being convicted .Under the legal definition , the defendant doesn ' t have to do anything . By comparison , the prosecution needs prove their case and establish all of the elements of a crime beyond a reasonable doubt .To be guilty , legally , means that the prosecution has proven your guilt beyond a reasonable doubt . This is a smaller threshold than the innocent burden of proof .

In contrast, the prosecution must prove their case and establish all elements of a crime beyond a reasonable doubt in order for someone to be legally guilty. This threshold is lower than the burden of proof for innocence.

text1:
Yes. In 1999, the Supreme Court decided a case called Green Tree Financial Corp.-Ala. v. Randolph, 531 U.S. 79 (2000), in which it affirmed a lower court’s decision to allow a consumer to pursue his claim of illegal “double charging” of interest in an arbitration forum. Although the consumer had to sign a contract that required arbitration, the contract did not specifically mention arbitration of claims under state law, such as the double charging issue, which was the basis of the consumer’s claim. The Supreme Court explained that this was not a barrier to the consumer’s right to have his claim arbitrated. That is, even though the parties may have agreed to limit the scope of arbitration to disputes between the parties that arose out of the agreement, and even though the parties did not specifically mention arbitration of claims under state law, that limitation in the agreement is overcome in federal arbitration statutes if the claim at issue is “within the scope or coverage of the arbitration agreement.”
The Green Tree decision permits consumers to file their claims of illegal interest charges in an arbitration forum. The consumer may be entitled to win a larger award than would be available under the arbitration agreement, but if the arbitrator follows the contract, the award may be limited to the amount provided for in the agreement.

The Supreme Court clarified that this was not a barrier to the customer ’ s right to have his claim arbitrated .That is , even though the parties may have decided to limit the scope of arbitration to disagreements between the parties that originated out of the deal , and even though the parties did not explicitly mention arbitration of claims under state legislation , that limitation in the accord is overcome in federal arbitration statutes if the claim at question is “ within the scope or coverage of the arbitration deal . ” The Green Tree decision allows consumers to submit their claims of illegal interest charges in an arbitration forum . The consumer might be entitled to win a greater award than would be available under the arbitration deal , but if the arbitrator follows the deal , the award may be restricted to the sum provided for in the deal .

text1:
(SOUTH TEXAS) Texas' "fetal heartbeat law" or (SB8), was signed into law on May 19, 2021 by Governor Abbot. In late June the law went into effect (on July 18th).
What Texas SB8 (Heartbeat Law) does is to ban abortions after 6 weeks, or after fetal cardiac activity is detected.
What makes Texas SB8 interesting is that it doesn't apply in the form of a State of Texas law. The Texas law actually places the enforcement of this law upon private citizens, via a process known as a "bounty" law.
Essentially, any person can sue another person who helps a woman get an abortion if they think it violates the Texas law. Under the law a plaintiff is allowed to recover a minimum of $10,000 in damages for every violation (per occurrence).
Now that Texas has officially entered this "heartbeat" law, the first challenge came yesterday (July 20, 2021) in the form of a federal lawsuit. The challenge is a suit filed by abortion clinics and others seeking a temporary restraining order against the law. Judge Kimba Wood in the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York is not holding a hearing until July 23, 2021.

In late June the law got into effect ( on July 18th ) .What Texas SB8 ( Heartbeat Law ) does is to prohibit abortions after 6 weeks , or after fetal cardiac activity is detected . What makes Texas SB8 important is that it doesn ' t apply in the form of a State of Texas law .The Texas law actually places the enforcement of this law upon private citizens , via a process known as a " bounty " law . Essentially , any person can sue another someone who assists a wife get an abortion if they believe it violates the Texas law .Under the law a plaintiff is allowed to regain a minimum of $ 10 , 000 in damages for every violation ( per occurrence ) . Now that Texas has officially entered this " heartbeat " law , the first challenge arrived yesterday ( July 20 , 2021 ) in the form of a federal lawsuit .The challenge is a suit filed by abortion clinics and others seeking a temporary restraining order against the law . text3: The southern region of Texas. Governor Abbot signed Texas' SB8, also known as the fetal cardiac law, into effect on May 19, 2021. The law went into effect on July 18th. The Heartbeat Law in Texas bans abortions after 6 weeks or once fetal cardiac activity is detected. The significance of Texas SB8 lies in its unique structure as a law that does not operate in the traditional state law format. The enforcement of the Texas law is carried out by private citizens through a "bounty" system. In essence, individuals can take legal action against anyone aiding a woman in obtaining an abortion if they believe it goes against Texas law. Individuals can receive at least $10,000 in damages for each violation of the law. The first legal challenge to Texas' Heartbeat Law came in the form of a federal lawsuit filed by abortion clinics and others seeking a temporary restraining order. Judge Kimba Wood in the Southern District of New York's Federal District Court will not have a hearing until July 23rd, 2021.

text1:
It is a piece of software that will rearrange your files and folder onto your disk to make it more efficient.
Q: why you should use Defragmentation
A: Files get fragmented because the computer needs to use up all of the free space to save your files. When a file is too big to fit into one contiguous space, it is put into pieces.
Another thing that causes fragmentation is reformatting the hard disk. The smaller the allocation size, the more frequently files get fragmented.
Also if the system needs to use up all of the free space to save a file, the smaller the free space is, the more likely that file will get fragmented.
Q: when you should use Defragmentation
A: When defragmentation first became a standard feature on PC’s, it was because you should do it regularly in order to keep your computer running at optimal speeds. However, research indicates that modern hard drives will usually stay pretty fast without much fragmentation.
Some experts even claim that defragmentation can be bad for a hard drive, and instead recommend to create more free space and then reformat the disk in order to make a nice, clean free space that does not have fragmented files. They then save the file on a new drive and then defragment it, usually this is a smaller drive like an external hard drive or flash drive.

Also if the system wants to use up all of the free space to save a file , the smaller the free space is , the more likely that file will getting fragmented .Q : when you should use Defragmentation A : When defragmentation initially appeared a basic feature on PC ’ s , it was because you should do it frequently in order to keep your laptop run at ideal speeds . However , research suggests that newer hard drives will usually stay quite fast without considerable fragmentation .Some specialists even argue that defragmentation can be bad for a hard drive , and instead advise to create more free space and then reformat the disk in order to make a decent , clean free space that does not have fragmented files . They then saving the file on a new drive and then defragment it , generally this is a smaller drive like an external hard drive or flash drive .
text3: The software will organize your files and folders on your disk for better efficiency. A: The reason for using Defragmentation is to improve efficiency. Fragmentation occurs when the computer needs to use all available free space to save files. When a file is too large to fit in one continuous space, it is divided into smaller pieces. Reformatting the hard disk also contributes to fragmentation. Files become fragmented more often with smaller allocation sizes. Defragmentation should be used when the system needs to save a file using all available free space, as smaller free space increases the likelihood of file fragmentation. Newer hard drives typically remain fast without significant fragmentation, leading some experts to believe that defragmentation may actually be harmful. They recommend creating more free space and reformatting the disk to achieve a clean, unfragmented free space. After saving the file on a new drive, they typically defragment it on a smaller drive such as an external hard drive or flash drive.

I have had this question asked of me twice in the last two days so I thought it would be a good opportunity to make a few comments on it. I am first going to mention some of the items covered in Roe v. Wade.
First, this is a trial that will determine if abortion is legal or illegal. I know that sounds simplistic, but abortion has been considered legal since the Roe v. Wade trial 40 years ago. The court decided that women had the right to choose to terminate their pregnancy and that right to abortion was not a problem.
I found two items in the Roe v. Wade trial very interesting. One is that the court decided that the fetus is not a person, so it has no rights. The other item I found interesting is that the court said if a fetus can feel pain, then it should be terminated. They also said the state should not stop a woman from killing her fetus in order to save her own life or health. The court went on to say that if an abortion were allowed to go forward and the fetus were alive, it would then have rights and the abortion would not be allowed. The court’s decision seems to say that abortion should be allowed, but not after the fetus is born.
The second item is that the Supreme Court ruled that abortion is legal in all 50 states and the U.S. territories. This decision should not be overturned unless it is the result of a court order, not a judicial ruling.

Felony murder is a theory that a person can be charged with murder if they commit a felony that causes someone to die.
A person can be convicted of murder if they are killed in the commission of a felony or if they intend to commit a felony and unintentionally cause the death of another person. They do not need the intent to kill.
A felony murder charge usually occurs when someone is killed in the course of another felony. For example, if two people are robbing a convenience store and someone is killed, the two people can be charged with felony murder.
The defendants in this case did not rob the victim or have an intent to rob him. They were accused of chasing the victim to speak to him.

A person can be convicted of murder if they are slain in the commission of a felony or if they intend to commit a felony and unintentionally cause the death of another someone .They do not require the intent to kill . A felony homicide charge usually occurs when person is slain in the course of another felony .For instance , if two people are robbing a convenience store and someone is assassinated , the two people can be charged with felony killings . The defendants in this case did not rob the victim or have an intent to rob him .They were accused of chasing the victim to speak to him.
text3: Felony murder is the concept that an individual can be charged with murder if they commit a felony that results in someone's death. A person can be found guilty of murder if they are killed during the commission of a felony or if they unintentionally cause someone's death while intending to commit a felony. Felony homicide charges typically arise when someone is killed during the commission of another felony. For example, if two individuals are robbing a convenience store and someone is killed, both individuals can be charged with felony murder. The defendants were not involved in robbing the victim or planning to do so, but they were accused of chasing him to have a conversation.

text1:
To the best of my knowledge, and judging by anecdotal evidence, the primary function of review bombing is not to encourage people to boycott (or otherwise not consume) the form of entertainment being bombed.
In fact, it seems review bombing is intended to simply be a “protest” of sorts, specifically one that is not actually directed at the entertainment itself, but rather at the people in power who represent the entertainment.
In this way, review bombing can also serve to inflict harm upon, or at the very least generate some degree of public criticism for, any and all people, businesses, or government officials who have any connection at all with the entertainment being reviewed.
In other words, review bombing is actually a type of social punishment.
In an actual “review bomb,” a large number of people submit malicious reviews of some form of entertainment. This has the result of artificially reducing the review scores of the entertainment in question. This is achieved by deliberately submitting a large number of reviews, many (or most) of which contain one- or two-word reviews containing offensive or otherwise inappropriate language.
Even if there are a large number of positive reviews, and even if the review scores of the entertainment are not artificially lowered by the review bombing, the site will still show the number of malicious reviews, along with the comments themselves, on the same page as the other reviews. The malicious reviews are visible to the general public, and remain so indefinitely.
text2: To the best of my knowledge , and judging by anecdotal evidence , the primary purpose of review bombing is not to promote everyone to boycott ( or otherwise not eat ) the form of entertainment being bombed . In reality , it appears review bombing is intended to simply be a “ protest ” of sorts , particularly one that is not actually directed at the entertainment itself , but rather at the people in power who represent the entertainment .In this way , review bombing can also serve to inflict damage upon , or at the very least create some degree of public disapproval for , any and all persons , businesses , or government officials who have any connection at all with the entertainment being evaluated . In other words , review bombing is actually a kind of social punishment .In an actual “ review bomb , ” a large number of people send malicious reviews of some kind of entertainment . This has the result of artificially decreasing the review scores of the entertainment in question .This is achieved by deliberately submitting a large number of reviews , many ( or most ) of which contain one - or two - word reviews featuring offensive or otherwise unacceptable language . Even if there are a large number of negative reviews , and even if the review scores of the entertainment are not artificially lowered by the review bombing , the site will still display the number of malicious reviews , along with the remarks themselves , on the same page as the other reviews .The malicious reviews are visible to the general public , and stay so indefinitely .
text3: As far as I know, review bombing is mainly done not to encourage people to boycott the entertainment being targeted. Review bombing seems to be more of a form of protest against those in power rather than the entertainment itself. In this manner, review bombing can also be used to harm or generate public disapproval for anyone associated with the entertainment being targeted. Review bombing is essentially a form of social retribution. A significant amount of individuals leave negative reviews for a specific form of entertainment. Deliberately submitting numerous offensive one or two-word reviews artificially lowers the review scores of the targeted entertainment. The website will continue to show the negative reviews, including the offensive remarks, alongside other reviews, even if the review scores are not affected by the review bombing. These malicious reviews will be permanently visible to the public.

Bail is an amount of money that can be posted to a court as a condition of pretrial release for a person charged with a crime. Bail helps assure the defendant will return to court and encourages pretrial release whenever possible. Bail can be posted in cash, property, or a surety bond from a bail bondsman. Bond companies charge a fee, which is usually 10% of the bond amount.
Q: Is the release of the accused only upon payment of the bail amount?
A: No. The most common conditions of bail are to not commit a crime, appear in court as ordered, obey a curfew, and report to a probation officer.
Q: What is a “surety bond”?
A: A surety bond is a bond provided by a bonding company that pays the amount of the bail if the defendant fails to appear in court. The defendant pays a non-refundable fee of 10% of the bail amount to the bonding company.
Q: How is the amount of bail set?
A: The amount of bail is based on the type of crime, the defendant’s criminal history, and the likelihood the defendant will return to court and pose a danger to the community. If you want to reduce your bail amount, you should obtain a lawyer immediately.
Q: I was given a bail bond. What does this mean?
A: A bond is a written promise to appear in court when and where ordered.

Typically a conviction for speeding or red light violation is reported to DMV.
Q: I was involved in a car accident, what is my obligation to exchange information with the other driver?
A: California Vehicle Code Section 16000 requires that when a person has been involved in a car accident which results in property damage in excess of $750.00, he or she must immediately stop their car and provide his or her name, address, drivers license number and insurance information to the other driver or any driver or the person or property damaged. If the other driver is incapacitated, the driver may leave the scene and notify law enforcement within 24 hours.
Q: What is the offense called when you make a left turn onto a busy street with the right turn only sign?
A: You made a left turn into the wrong lane, which is a violation of CVC 21964. The consequences are a $70 fine. However, your insurance rates may be increased for five years. If you commit the offense in an accident, it can be construed as a hit and run.
Q: What are the possible consequences if I am caught driving without insurance?
A: California Department of Motor Vehicles requires that every driver show financial responsibility for all drivers and passengers in the vehicle. Insurance is the only type of financial responsibility that is acceptable. Proof of insurance is required to renew your vehicle registration. If you do not have insurance, your vehicle registration will not be renewed.

text1:
A bill is the first step of the legislative process, which is a pathway to passing a law. The Legislative Branch of the United States Congress has the power to enact laws, also known as legislation, for the entire country. A bill is legislation that is introduced in Congress. For example, the U.S. Senate needs 60 members to pass a bill, which is known as a filibuster. Only 50 votes are required to pass a bill in the House of Representatives.
Q: How are senators and representatives chosen?
A: Representatives serve for a two-year term. Every two years, there are 435 members who are chosen. However, only one member is chosen for each state. If a member of Congress does not complete their term, an election can be held for a replacement. A congressman will be chosen if the seat is open. The 100 senators have six-year terms. Two senators are chosen for each state, and one of them will represent the state for the duration of that term.
Q: When do new laws go into effect?
A: Laws take effect when they are published in the Federal Register. New federal rules go into effect immediately. However, state laws are given time to make adjustments before they are enforced. Federal laws are called statutes. State laws are called statutes.
Q: What is a joint resolution?
A: A joint resolution is a motion to approve or disapprove a bill. Joint resolutions are often used to vote on appropriations or similar issues.

text1:
Open your mind, watch your reactions.
There is a paradox with the idea of tolerance, at least for those of us who belong to a dominant culture or identity. If we open our minds, we will necessarily be exposed to views and practices with which we do not necessarily agree, and, inevitably, come to question some of our own values and the views of others. This can be uncomfortable. Tolerance can be a trap.
I will use a metaphor: tolerance is like a spider’s web, and intolerance is like a fish trap. Intolerance might be attractive because the lure is alluring, the set up seems solid and clear, and the payoff might be emotional fulfillment. Tolerance, on the other hand, might seem messy, unclear and illusory. For some, the tension, discomfort, and uncertainty that comes with trying to live out tolerance is not worth the temporary contentment of closeness, similarity and security that comes with intolerance. If you fall for the spider’s web, you might be caught and experience some pain. Or you might see the empty lures for what they are, and be free to come and go as you choose.
We all have, at some point in our lives, fallen for intolerance. The illusion of safety and security has been powerful, and a degree of pain and misunderstanding inevitable. And, in each of our lives, we have, at some point in our lives, probably discovered or rediscovered the lessons of tolerance.

We all have , at some time in our lives , fallen for intolerance .The illusion of security and protection has been powerful , and a degree of pain and misunderstanding inevitable . And , in each of our lives , we have , at some time in our lives , probably found or rediscovered the lessons of tolerance .
text3: Be open-minded and pay attention to how you react. The concept of tolerance can be paradoxical for individuals from dominant cultures or identities. When we are open-minded, we will encounter differing views and practices that may challenge our own beliefs and values. This may feel uncomfortable. can be a tricky situation. Intolerance can be appealing due to its enticing lure, clear setup, and potential emotional rewards, while tolerance is compared to a spider's web in this metaphor. In contrast, tolerance may seem chaotic, ambiguous, and deceptive. The discomfort and anxiety of practicing tolerance may not seem worth it compared to the temporary contentment and protection that intolerance offers. If you get caught in the spider's web, you could be ensnared and go through pain. Recognizing the false attractions can allow you to have the freedom to come and go as you please. At some point in our lives, we have all been drawn to intolerance, enticed by the false sense of security it offers despite the inevitable pain and misunderstandings that come with it. At some point in our lives, we have all likely learned or relearned the importance of tolerance.

text1:
Qualified immunity is an  immunity from suit  for a government official for actions taken while in office. It protects those holding public office from being sued for discretionary actions undertaken in the course of their duties.
In the United States, qualified immunity is a judicially created doctrine. It has received the approval of the Supreme Court of the United States in cases from  1967  and  1977.
The doctrine is controversial because many critics, including many legal scholars, say it allows too many government officials, especially law enforcement, to violate the rights of the people.
Qualified immunity allows government officials to do their job without the constant threat of a lawsuit or the inability to work their jobs because of a litigation climate. It frees government officials to focus on doing their jobs rather than the threat of lawsuits.
The doctrine has been criticized by some for being too broad and used to protect too many government officials, even those acting in the most egregious circumstances.
text2: Qualified immunity is an immunity from suit for a government official for actions taken while in office . It protects those holding government office from being sued for discretionary actions undertaken in the course of their duties .In the United States , qualified immunity is a judicially created doctrine . It has obtained the approval of the Supreme Court of the United States in cases from 1967 and 1977 .The doctrine is controversial because several critics , including much legal scholars , think it allows too many government officials , particularly law enforcement , to violate the rights of the people . Qualified immunity means government officials to do their job without the frequent threat of a complaint or the failure to work their jobs because of a litigation climate .It frees government officials to focus on doing their jobs rather than the threat of lawsuits . The doctrine has been attacked by some for being too broad and utilized to protect too many public executives , even those acted in the most egregious circumstances .
text3: Government officials are protected from being sued for their actions while in office through qualified immunity. Qualified immunity shields government officials from legal action for their discretionary actions performed during their official responsibilities. In the United States, qualified immunity is a doctrine that was established by the courts. The doctrine of qualified immunity has been endorsed by the Supreme Court in cases from 1967 and 1977, but it is a subject of controversy as many critics, including legal scholars, believe it enables government officials, especially law enforcement, to infringe on people's rights too easily. Qualified immunity allows government officials to focus on their duties without constant fear of legal action, enabling them to perform their jobs effectively. Critics argue that the doctrine is overly broad and often used to shield public officials, even in cases of extreme misconduct.

“When a person dies by an act which the deceased is unlikely to have foreseen, such as a freak accident or an adventure which goes wrong, it is termed as accidental death and the cause of death is misadventure. ”
Q: What is severe bodily harm?
A: “It’s another way of saying serious bodily harm, that is, the intent is to cause grievous bodily harm or serious injury to the complainant. ”
Q: What is grievous bodily harm?
A: “It’s a very serious injury to the victim. Grievous bodily harm can include disfigurement or permanent damage, such as the removal of part of a victim’s brain or eye, as well as impairing the victim’s health permanently or temporarily.”
Q: What is assault?
A: “You may use actual force, or threat of force, to assault another person. Actual force is where you do something that the law recognises as an assault. Threat of force is when you threaten to assault another person. ”
Q: What is serious assault?
A: “Serious assault is one that is considered serious by the courts. For example, an assault where the offender intended to rob the victim. ”
Q: What is sexual assault?
A: “Sexual assault is sexual touching of another person without the person’s consent. Sexual assault includes: ”
A: “If you commit any of these acts towards another person, it is sexual assault.

text1:
Before we delve into the question I want to share an experience with you. I'm one of those guys who always carry at least a couple of hundred dollars in cash in my wallet. There's a good chance that it's a new crisp bill, however, even if it's not I still count it as currency and that's a key component in this scenario. A long time ago I used to work in the sub-culture of people who, for one reason or another, were living very "off-the-grid." And during those days I learned several things about carrying money.
The most important thing I learned was that cash in general, and lots of cash in particular, are targets for people who are desperate. But, if you find yourself in an argument (e.g. "you dropped this $100 bill" or "you owe me for this thing") where the other party (or parties) is (are) holding a gun to your head, the way to survive is to give them the cash in your wallet.
Here's why: If you have $200 in cash, you have a 100% chance of losing your life, and a 100% chance of losing your money. But if you give them the $200 they are holding and, say, they take your wallet and only find $80 in it, you have an 80% chance of losing your life, and a 20% chance of losing your money.

text1: This is an interesting question with a short answer. Police are civil servants, and civil servants in the UK are governed by employment contracts. Air traffic controllers are, or used to be, employed directly by the Government under terms and conditions specified in the Civil Service Conditions of Service. The State does not recognise the right of civil servants to strike. In the recent past, this has had to be enforced at some airports by calling in soldiers to control the air traffic. You can see why they don't want to repeat that experience.

It's understandable why they would want to avoid going through that again.

text1:
Am I the only one who is baffled by the idea that professional set armorers and props masters somehow, under any circumstances, are no substitute for actually doing things correctly, personally?
Tangent on purpose: if this is actually how it goes, then I don’t see how hiring an actual CBRNE instructor could possibly help save lives in an active shooter situation. But I digress.
While it is true that actors typically do point guns at other actors, it is not true that you should ever treat a gun like it is unloaded, and especially not in light of the tragic incident in Baldwin’s case. No way is that a thing that can be permitted.
Further, the roles in a movie are being shot one at a time, one side of the gun is being shot, and the actor never points the gun at anything. The only thing that happens is that people walk off with empty guns, and then someone else walks on with the exact same gun, still pointed in the exact same direction, which seems… Well, unsafe, to say the least.
Worse, I do not believe any of the training that movie actors get actually addresses the live-fire portions of the event. Hollywood actors don’t learn much of anything about guns outside of props mastery and some “stage combat” (which doesn’t involve anything resembling a live weapon).

In movies, scenes are filmed one by one with only one side of the gun being shown, and the characters never aim the gun at anyone. text1:
All clients first have a copy of the repository server ID for trust. When you deploy a project, you request that the files be locked so you can work on them, and then, as a last step, you sign the new data you just checked out with your ID, not the server's. This works well for you, the project owner. No one else can come along, read your changes, copy the changes, and then claim that they made the changes. They cannot successfully cheat you out of your work, and they have a means to certify the authenticity of the data. The key to the whole system is that anyone can then audit this process to see if you really are the project owner.
Repudiation attacks occur when the file's creator denies that the file is his own. In Git, a file's creator is tracked as a record, rather than by a signature on the data itself. The creator does not automatically have to be the person creating the current record, nor does he have to be in possession of the file. Thus, a repudiation attack is easy to execute because the creator can claim that he did not create the current version. The file, therefore, contains no history that says otherwise.
text2: All clients first have a copy of the repository server ID for trust . When you deploy a project , you demand that the files be sealed so you can work on them , and then , as a last step , you sign the new data you just scanned out with your ID , not the server ' s .This works well for you , the project owner . No one else can come along , see your changes , copy the changes , and then deny that they made the changes .They cannot effectively cheat you out of your work , and they have a means to certify the authenticity of the information . The key to the whole system is that someone can then audit this process to see if you truly are the project owner .Repudiation attacks happens when the file ' s creator denies that the file is his own . In Git , a file ' s creator is tracked as a record , rather than by a signature on the information itself .The creator does not automatically have to be the person producing the present record , nor does he have to be in possession of the file . Thus , a repudiation attack is easy to execute because the creator can assert that he did not construct the present version .The file , thus , contains no history that says otherwise .
text3: Every client is provided with a copy of the repository server ID to establish trust. When deploying a project, you require the files to be locked for editing, and then you digitally sign the updated data with your personal ID instead of the server's. This is beneficial for you as the project owner. Others cannot view, replicate, or falsely claim authorship of your changes, ensuring the integrity and authenticity of your work. The system allows for auditing to verify your ownership of the project, and repudiation attacks occur when the file's creator denies ownership. In Git, the file's creator is identified through a record rather than a signature on the data itself, allowing for flexibility in ownership and possession of the file. Therefore, it is simple for a repudiation attack to occur when the creator denies creating the current version, as there is no history in the file to prove otherwise.

text1:
Academic dismissal is the process of removing a student from the University due to poor academic performance and unsatisfactory or unacceptable student behavior.
Q: What is the difference between administrative dismissal and academic dismissal?
A: An administrative dismissal is usually for violations of the Student Code of Conduct, while an academic dismissal is related to academic performance and/or unsatisfactory or unacceptable student behavior.
Q: How is a student notified of academic dismissal?
A: The student is notified by official email to his or her UICmail account as well as by registered USPS mail.
Q: How do I appeal my academic dismissal?
A: Download the PDF of the Academic Appeal form to request the appeal process.
Q: How do I pay my reinstatement fee?
A: Students may pay their reinstatement fee online via their WebPay accounts or in person at the Cashier’s Office, located in the Student Services Building, 1200 W. Harrison St., RM 103.
Q: What is my appeal schedule?
A: Students must complete the appeal process by the deadline indicated in the dismissal email.
Q: Is there any help available to me?
A: Please visit the Enrollment Services, UIC Student Success Centers located in the Student Services Building, 1200 W. Harrison St., RM 150.
