text1:
legalizing marijuana has come up time and time again, mostly because a majority of people support legalizing marijuana for medical purposes and more recently, recreational purposes. But what does this really mean? Decriminalization has come up as a reasonable alternative to full legalization. But what is the difference?
Decriminalization is just the first step toward legalization. If a drug is decriminalized, that means people are no longer going to prison for possessing or using the drug. It does not mean, however, that you are free to do with the drug what you want without penalty.
This often means there is no jail time, but there may be fines for possession or use, or a fine for public use, etc. There are still barriers to access, if you have to pay to have it or use it or if it is only used in a specific place, the drug remains somewhat illegal.
What full legalization means is that the drug can be used, sold, and purchased in a regulated and legal way. Marijuana is regulated just like alcohol, but much more like tobacco, because of its effect on a human's body. This means that there are age requirements, restrictions on where the drugs can be sold or purchased, and taxes on the product and its sale.
A significant difference between alcohol and marijuana is that there is not a lot of large scale corporate money going into marijuana production yet.

This often implies there is no jail time , but there may be sentences for possession or use , or a fine for public use , etc .There are still obstacles to access , if you have to pay to have it or use it or if it is only used in a certain place , the drug becomes somewhat illegal . What complete legalization means is that the drug can be used , sell , and obtained in a controlled and legal way .Marijuana is controlled just like liquor , but much more like smoking , because of its impact on a human ' s body . This means that there are age regulations , rules on where the drugs can be sold or bought , and taxes on the product and its sale .A significant difference between drinking and marijuana is that there is not a lot of large scale corporate money going into marijuana production yet .
text3: The topic of legalizing marijuana has been brought up repeatedly, as many people support its legalization for both medical and recreational use. What are the implications of this? Decriminalization is being considered as a more reasonable option than full legalization. What distinguishes the two options? Decriminalization is seen as a precursor to full legalization. Decriminalization means that individuals will not be incarcerated for possessing or using the drug, but it does not grant complete freedom to use the drug without consequences. Decriminalization typically means no imprisonment, but there may still be penalties for possession or use, such as fines for public consumption. Access to the drug may still be restricted by costs or limited locations, making it somewhat illegal. Full legalization of marijuana allows for regulated use, sale, and acquisition of the drug, similar to alcohol but with more similarities to smoking due to its effects on the body. This entails regulations on age, locations for sale and purchase, and taxation on the product and its distribution. One major distinction between alcohol and marijuana is the lack of substantial corporate investment in marijuana production at this time.

Therefore, only values of F larger than 1 would lead us to reject the null hypothesis, which means that a one-tail test is required.

text1:
In the United States, the separation of church and state is not an absolute principle. It is not even enshrined in the Constitution. The principle is that government shall not establish a state religion, nor sponsor, promote or influence any religious activity.
But it is an inherent aspect of our rights to religious freedom, which is a right that has a particular role in American history, and is an exception to the general rule that the government can be whatever is the majority opinion.
We can examine this question by taking a look at the separation of church and state as it applies to today’s politics, and as it relates to political philosophy. The latter is not just interesting in itself. It can also provide insight into how the idea of separation of church and state has become distorted, and what it can mean in today’s context. It also offers some clarity about the principle of separation of church and state.
Read more: How much should the church interfere with state matters?
When the phrase “separation of church and state” was coined by the Virginia House of Burgesses in 1774, it was in response to a petition by the Anglican Church asking for a tax. The petitioners said that the church was being discriminated against, as the other Protestant denominations were exempt from taxes.
The state had a right to tax the church, they said.

However, the concept of separating church and state is a fundamental aspect of our freedom of religious liberty, playing a significant role in American history and serving as an exception to the government following the majority opinion. This can be explored by looking at how the separation of church and state influences today's politics and political beliefs. The latter is not only interesting on its own. text1:
An original post at Unfiltered Myths questioned whether good behavior should be rewarded and bad behavior punished regardless of intent. The original question being: if a teacher is kind, would they still punish their students for being late? Would a principle reward a child that did their homework and then intentionally be late for school?
From what I’ve seen, the answer is no. We punish people for their behavior more so than their intent. That’s because outcome is easier to measure. We can all agree that a student being late is bad behavior. It would require an empathetic teacher or principle to reward a student that did their homework and then intentionally be late. Although the “intent” for the student to be late was different than a student that was genuinely late, it would likely be the exact same punishment as the student that was late because they were late regardless of intent.
When looking at the statement “good behavior should be rewarded and bad behavior punished regardless of intent”, consider whether it’s more easily measured to measure a person’s outcome or intent. We could argue that in some instances, we should only measure outcome and reward or punish based on behavior. Then there are those instances where measuring intent makes more sense. But which comes more easily, measuring outcome or intent?
Then of course, there are times where both intent and outcome have a huge bearing on how we reward and punish people. So you are not late to school this morning, but you have just been texting and driving.
text2: An original post at Unfiltered Myths challenged whether great conduct should be rewarded and good behavior punished regardless of intent . The original question being : if a educator is kind , would they still punish their students for being late ?Would a principle reward a kid that did their homework and then intentionally be late for school ? From what I ’ ve seen , the answer is no .We punish people for their actions more so than their intent . That ’ s because result is easier to measure .We can all agree that a pupil being late is bad conduct . It would need an empathetic tutor or principle to reward a pupil that did their homework and then intentionally be late .Although the “ intent ” for the student to be late was different than a student that was truly late , it would probably be the exact same punishment as the student that was late because they were late regardless of intent . When looking at the statement “ good behavior should be rewarded and good behavior punished regardless of intent ” , consider whether it ’ s more easily measured to measure a person ’ s outcome or intent .We may suggest that in some instances , we should only measure outcome and reward or punish based on behavior . Then there are those instances where measuring intent becomes more sense .But which comes more easily , measuring outcome or intent ? Then of course , there are times where both intent and outcome have a huge bearing on how we reward and punish people .So you are not early to class this morning , but you have just been texting and driving .
text3: A post on Unfiltered Myths questioned the idea of rewarding good behavior and punishing bad behavior without considering intent. The question posed was whether a kind educator would still punish students for being late. Would a principal reward a student who completed their homework but purposely arrived late to school? Based on my observations, the answer is negative. Focus on holding individuals accountable for their actions rather than their intentions. This is because outcomes are more quantifiable. It is generally accepted that a student arriving late is considered inappropriate behavior. An empathetic educator or principal would be required to reward a student who completed their homework but intentionally arrived late. Regardless of the student's intent, they would likely receive the same punishment for being late as a student who was genuinely late. Consider whether it is more practical to measure a person's outcomes or intentions when determining how to reward good behavior and punish bad behavior. It may be implied that sometimes we should focus solely on outcomes and base rewards or punishments on behavior. In some cases, it may be more practical to focus on measuring intent. However, determining whether it is easier to measure outcomes or intentions remains a question. Sometimes, both intent and outcome play a significant role in determining how we reward and punish individuals. You arrived late to class this morning because you were texting and driving.

text1:
Robert Martin’s June 16 letter (to the Editor) was interesting, but wrong.
Under Texas law, a House Speaker may control “debate” and the use of the House floor. During this control, a speaker may ban language, calls and yelling out of any words or language. Of course, “racism” or “racialism” would qualify. The right of free speech of House members does not allow them to disrespect the speaker, especially when the majority of members vote for the speaker to be in that position.
As a result, Bob Martin is wrong about this.  The speaker can set the tone, and rules of debate.  The Speaker does not ban words, he sets the rules of debate.  He is not a dictator; he is an elected officer of the Legislature.
Let us not forget, there are rules of order for debate of the House, which are set by the Parliamentarian of the House of Representatives.
Then the words he used are left up to the definition of the dictionary, “A person with a prejudice or discrimination.”  Such a person or person or group could be controlled by the person in authority.  The Texas Supreme Court would be the final arbiter.
Richard Henry Shelton Jr., former president, Friendswood Rotary Club, Quail Valley Country Club, former president, Deer Park Civitan Club
What is the Texas Lege considering now? Time for citizens to become involved.

text1:
The First Amendment to the U.S. Constitution states, “Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances.”
The Establishment Clause keeps the government from establishing a state religion. It does not force any citizen to support or refrain from supporting religion or faith. It does not forbid references to religion in the public sphere, as the aforementioned Representatives’ remarks have proven. And the Constitution itself was written with a religious context and influence. That is just the nature of the U.S. and its people. The First Amendment does not compel Americans to reject religion, as is commonly claimed by atheists and “secularists.”
The spirit of the First Amendment is not to reject religion; it is to prevent the government from “establishing” a religion. As the Founders noted, it is intended to keep religious leaders from getting too much power. The Founders did not intend for this to be a purely secular society where religion was forbidden in public or private life. In fact, James Madison once declared, “The purpose of separation of church and state is to keep forever from these shores the ceaseless strife that has soaked the soil of Europe in blood for centuries.” This has nothing to do with rejecting religion. It is to promote a free society.

text1:
the noun form of the gerund or present participle of the verb mansplain (as defined by urban dictionary )
urban dictionary  said " mansplain  is short for ‘man-spexify’ to explain something to a person who is known to have full or adequate knowledge or experience of the thing being explained. There are both male and female mansplainers. "
One website did say,  " It’s just annoying to have a conversation with a mansplainer."   I disagree.  I think it is more than annoying.  It is bullying.  And they are everywhere.  And it happens to me on a regular basis.
On June 23, 2015 when I first wrote this, mansplaining had been on my radar since 2011.  I wrote about it often, and yet still I was plagued by it almost daily.

This is probably a good place to note that neither the answer to the second question nor the security of the biometric solution is the only consideration for making a decision in a corporate environment.
Relying on a passcode is much more secure than biometric methods. A biometric scan can be spoofed, copied, or obtained through coercion.
Biometric IDs can be lifted from a dead person. Passcodes are linked to individuals and identities that are assumed to be offline when the person who holds them is deceased.
Finally, the identification algorithm used to compare biometric identifiers can be attacked in order to find and reconstruct a fingerprint or the speaker’s face. Reconstructing a password is not likely.

text1:
A plea bargain between the accused and the prosecutor typically includes a promise by the accused to plead guilty in exchange for the prosecutor’s promise to offer a significantly shorter sentence than would be imposed if the case were decided at trial. This outcome is more likely to occur when the prosecutor believes that he or she can prove their case at trial. The prosecutor may, for example, find the defendant’s testimony to be more credible than the defendant’s witnesses. Or the prosecutor may feel that the evidence is so strong that a jury is unlikely to acquit the defendant. Or the prosecutor may determine that the case presents complicated evidentiary issues which may not be resolved in the defendant’s favor.
Q: What is a “no contest” plea?
A: “No contest” means that the defendant admits the conduct alleged in the complaint is true, but denies guilt, in other words the defendant maintains that he did not commit the crime. Therefore, a “no contest” plea is not an admission of guilt, but is treated the same as a guilty plea for purposes of sentencing.
Q: How is a trial different from a hearing?
A: A trial involves witnesses testifying before a jury who determine whether the government has met its burden of proving the case beyond a reasonable doubt. At the trial, witnesses are not limited to the events that occurred on the date of the alleged crime. At trial, the defense has the opportunity to present evidence, and may present witnesses.

Or the prosecutor could feel that the proof is so powerful that a jury is unlikely to acquit the defendant .Or the prosecutor could determine that the case presents difficult evidentiary questions which may not be resolved in the defendant ’ s favor . Q : What is a “ no contest ” pleading ?A : “ No contest ” means that the defendant admits the actions alleged in the complaint is true , but denies guilt , in other words the defendant asserts that he did not commit the criminal . Therefore , a “ no contest ” plea is not an admission of guilt , but is treated the same as a guilty plea for purposes of sentencing .Q : How is a prosecution separate from a hearing ? A : A trial includes witnesses testifying before a jury who determine whether the government has meeting its burden of finding the case beyond a reasonable doubt .At the trial , witnesses are not limited to the events that occurred on the date of the alleged criminal . At trial , the defense has the opportunity to provide evidence , and may present witnesses .
text3: A plea bargain involves the accused agreeing to plead guilty in exchange for a shorter sentence from the prosecutor compared to what would be given at trial. This outcome is more probable when the prosecutor is confident in their ability to prove the case at trial, such as by finding the defendant's testimony more believable. Alternatively, the prosecutor may believe that the evidence is strong enough that the defendant is unlikely to be acquitted by a jury. the prosecutor may find that the case involves challenging evidentiary issues that may not work out in the defendant's favor. What does a "no contest" plea entail? A "no contest" plea involves the defendant admitting to the actions alleged in the complaint as true, but denying guilt by asserting that they did not commit the crime. A "no contest" plea is considered the same as a guilty plea in terms of sentencing, even though it does not admit guilt. During a trial, witnesses provide testimony to a jury who then decides if the government has proven the case beyond a reasonable doubt. During the trial, witnesses can testify about more than just what happened on the day of the crime. During a trial, the defense can present evidence and call witnesses to testify.

Q: If I lived in California and bought a new $300,000.00 home, can I be forced to pay 5% more taxes because of a 50% increase in local property value? There has been no work done on my home whatsoever.
A: Yes. That’s not how it works, but that’s not important. The idea is that real estate in some areas is inflated by the simple fact that it’s real estate, not because it has much inherent value. The cost of maintaining the home is not fixed to the property value. Instead, as property values rise, so do the costs to maintain the home. Yet, this happens with a lag. Also, once prices rise, the fact that prices are higher makes maintenance more costly because it’s more difficult to find skilled workers at lower prices. This happens because employers with money compete to hire the workers, which drives up the cost of hiring the workers.
Q: While I was living in the country, I was driving at a speed of 30mph, with lights on and a shoulder seat belt fastened. I saw in my mirror a police cruiser and automatically put my turn signal on (I was going to turn anyway). I then heard the police car honking at me so I stopped.

text1: Some cases are decided solely by the judge, who is the fact-finder, while others are decided by a jury which acts as the fact-finder. In most cases, however, the jury decides the facts while the judge decides the law. In general, civil cases are decided by a judge, unless you or your adversary demand a jury trial. In all criminal cases, however, the defendant has the constitutional right to a trial by jury.

text1:
Suppose you have a table of information such as the one on page 37 of Rosenblum's "Quantum Enigma". Let's look at just the information in the top 2 rows of the table.
According to classical physics, the measuring device is always (on average) in a definite location, and there is a definite (infinite) number of ways for the electron to be located within the measuring device. Therefore, by calculating the probability of measuring the electron in 10^79 different locations, one is calculating the probability that the measuring device will have 10^79 positions (on average) which are possible (infinitely probable) locations of the electron.
According to quantum physics, the measuring device can be in an indefinite location, and there is a definite (finite) number of ways for the electron to be located within the measuring device. Therefore, by calculating the probability of measuring the electron in 10^3 different locations, one is calculating the probability that the measuring device will have 10^3 possible (definitely possible) locations of the electron.
In classical physics, the measuring device always has an infinite number of possible locations of the electron. In quantum physics, the measuring device only has a finite number of possible locations of the electron.
Classical physics says that the measuring device (on average) has 10^79 positions which are (infinitely) possible locations of the electron.
text2: Suppose you have a table of information such as the one on page 37 of Rosenblum ' s " Quantum Enigma " . Let ' s glance at just the information in the top 2 rows of the table .According to classical physics , the measuring instrument is usually ( on average ) in a definite places , and there is a definite ( infinite ) number of ways for the electron to be located within the measuring instrument . Therefore , by calculating the probability of measuring the electron in 10 ^ 79 different places , one is calculating the probability that the measuring instrument will have 10 ^ 79 positions ( on average ) which are possible ( infinitely likely ) locations of the electron .According to quantum mechanics , the measuring instrument can be in an indefinite location , and there is a definite ( finite ) number of ways for the electron to be located within the measuring instrument . Therefore , by calculating the probability of measuring the electron in 10 ^ 3 different places , one is calculating the probability that the measuring instrument will have 10 ^ 3 possible ( definitely possible ) locations of the electron .In classical physics , the measuring instrument always has an endless number of possible locations of the electron . In quantum physics , the measuring instrument only has a finite number of possible destinations of the electron .Classical physics said that the measuring instrument ( on average ) has 10 ^ 79 positions which are ( infinitely ) possible locations of the electron .
text3: Imagine you have a data table like the one found on page 37 of Rosenblum's book "Quantum Enigma". Let's focus on the data in the first two rows of the table. In classical physics, the measuring instrument is typically in a specific position on average, and there are numerous possible locations for the electron within the instrument. Calculating the probability of finding the electron in numerous locations also calculates the likelihood of the measuring instrument being in multiple positions. Calculating the probability of finding the electron in 10^3 different places also determines the likelihood of the measuring instrument having 10^3 possible locations for the electron. In classical physics, the measuring instrument has an infinite number of potential electron locations. In quantum physics, the measuring instrument has a limited number of potential electron locations compared to classical physics. In physics, the measuring instrument is said to have an average of 10^79 positions, all of which are potential locations for the electron.

text1: I shall start by explaining the similarities then the differences because this is the question and also most people would tend to start a piece of work this way. Both the Police and the FBI are part of the same governing body. The FBI in particular has a department that is a part of the national police structure called the Federal Police Service. The Federal Police Service is an operational force that provides support to the FBI and other law enforcement agencies in areas such as: crime scene management, firearms regulation, vehicle registration, explosives licensing, security screening, guarding sensitive national installations and the supervision and control of public demonstrations and so on. Within the national police structure the FBI is made up of three major divisions, the first being the Criminal Investigation Department (CID). They investigate crimes such as murder, fraud, extortion and drug trafficking; they also provide specialist advice and training in areas such as photography, fingerprints and fingerprinting, forensic, controlled drugs, firearms, major crime investigations, management, building searches, reconstruction of crime scenes, and media presentations. Secondly, the Organised Crime Division (OCD), which investigates offences involving organised crime and drug trafficking, and thirdly the Support Division (SPD) which provides specialist and technical support to investigators by managing and maintaining the physical evidence control system and safe, fingerprint recognition systems, and specialist mobile search and investigation teams. These teams deal with: major crimes involving firearms, motor vehicle theft, arson, sexual offences, child abuse and white-collar crime.

It is a sign of respect. Because he or she has gone through the legal system and become a judge.
Q: - Why do all legal proceedings start at 9:30?
A: This goes back to the old days of horse and buggy. Back then the judge's work day began at 9:30, but in winter his work day ended at noon. His system was that the trials would start at 9:30 regardless of the weather, so that by the time the jury was impaneled and the lawyers ready to proceed, the judge would usually be ready to go home.
Q: - Why do defendants plead guilty when they are innocent?
A: To avoid trial costs, court costs, child care, transportation costs to and from the court house, etc. The defendant realizes that if he or she receives probation (whatever that may be) it is not worth the hassle.
Q: - Why is the judge dressed differently than the lawyers and the jury?
A: He or she wears the robe because of the respect that should be given to the judge by the parties who appear before him or her.

text1:
Plot twists are what we use in narrative fiction to create dramatic tension and surprise.
“Surprise” can come from two directions: Something the reader didn't know, or something the reader did know. Both can create a temporary emotional charge that draws the reader in. But surprise is the shock value, not the point. Plot twists exist to accomplish a goal in the story: To ratchet up the tension, to make a dramatic change, to get the characters out of a tight spot, to reveal a plot point, to establish some truth about the characters.
Authors can hide things from us in two ways. The most important method is to choose an effective hiding place, or a “threat point” (a term I believe I learned from Nathan Bransford).
If you have a character that we assume is dead, but then reveal at the end that they’re actually alive, you have created a perfect hiding place. We know this character is dead, and so that means we will look to see if they’re dead. So they’re in the perfect hiding place.
Similarly, if we think the heroine is having a mundane illness (something like chicken pox), but then she turns out to have the black plague, then that illness is hiding right out in the open. Since we don’t suspect anything, we won’t be looking for anything. So it's a perfect hiding place. That's the kind of hiding place we want.
There are all kinds of hiding places.
text2: Plot twists are what we using in narrative fiction to create dramatic tension and surprise . “ Surprise ” can come from two directions : Something the viewer didn ' t know , or something the viewer did know .Both can create a temporary emotional charge that draws the viewer in . But surprise is the shock value , not the point .Plot twists occur to achieve a goal in the story : To ratchet up the tension , to make a dramatic change , to getting the protagonists out of a tight spot , to reveal a plot point , to create some truth about the protagonists . Authors can conceal stuff from us in two ways .The most important method is to choose an efficient hiding area , or a “ threat point ” ( a word I believe I learned from Nathan Bransford ) . If you have a character that we assume is dead , but then reveal at the end that they ’ re actually alive , you have created a perfect hiding area .We understand this character is dead , and so that means we will look to see if they ’ re dead . So they ’ re in the perfect hiding area .Similarly , if we thought the heroine is having a mundane condition ( something like chicken pox ) , but then she turns out to have the dark virus , then that infection is hidden right out in the open . Since we don ’ t suspect anybody , we won ’ t be looking for anything .So it ' s a perfect hiding point . That ' s the kind of hid place we want .There are all sorts of hid spots .
text3: We use plot twists in narrative fiction to generate dramatic tension and unexpected surprises. "Surprise can be created by revealing something unknown to the viewer or by confirming something the viewer already knew, both of which can evoke a temporary emotional response that captivates the viewer." The main focus is not on the element of surprise, but rather on the plot itself. Plot twists serve various purposes in a story, such as increasing tension, creating dramatic changes, resolving conflicts, unveiling important plot points, and revealing truths about the characters. Writers can hide information from readers by strategically choosing a "threat point" or an effective hiding place. Creating a plot twist where a character believed to be dead is actually alive serves as an effective hiding place in the story. We believe this character is dead, so we will investigate to confirm their fate. They are in an ideal hiding spot. If we initially believed the heroine had a common illness like chicken pox, but it is later revealed she actually has a serious virus, then the infection was cleverly concealed in plain sight. If we don't suspect anyone, we won't be searching for anything. It serves as an ideal hiding spot. That is the perfect hiding spot we are looking for. Various hiding spots exist.

Contrary to popular belief, evidence does not have to be signed and sworn to as a statement made under oath in order to be admissible at trial. One example of admissible evidence that does not have to be signed and sworn to is the defendant’s handwritten notebook, which defense attorneys call a “DIY confessional” because the defendant writes out his confession. If a defense attorney is very lucky, he might also be able to include in his case-in-chief the defendant’s electronic communications with others, including emails and text messages. This type of evidence would also not have to be sworn to and signed as a statement made under oath, but would still be admissible.
It is important to distinguish between evidence (i.e., a thing that tends to prove or disprove something) and evidence that is subject to exclusionary rules of law. The Fourth Amendment, for example, provides that “[t]he right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated, and no Warrants shall issue, but upon probable cause, supported by Oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to be searched, and the persons or things to be seized.” Thus, a search warrant can only be obtained upon probable cause and supported by oath. If the search is conducted without a search warrant, the evidence is subject to the exclusionary rule.
text2: Contrary to popular view , proof does not have to be signed and sworn to as a document given under oath in order to be admissible at trial . One example of admissible proof that does not have to be signed and sworn to is the defendant ’ s handwritten notebook , which defense attorneys call a “ DIY confessional ” because the defendant writes out his confession .If a defense attorney is very lucky , he would also be able to include in his case - in - chief the defendant ’ s electronic communications with others , particularly emails and text signals . This kind of evidence would also not have to be swear to and signed as a statement made under oath , but would still be admissible .It is important to distinguish between testimony ( i . e . , a thing that tends to confirm or disprove something ) and evidence that is subject to exclusionary laws of law . The Fourth Amendment , for example , offers that “ [ t ] he right of the people to be secure in their persons , houses , papers , and effects , against unreasonable searches and seizures , shall not be violated , and no Warrants shall issue , but upon probable cause , backed by Oath or affirmation , and particularly describing the place to be raided , and the persons or things to be seized . ” Thus , a search warrant can only be obtained upon probable cause and backed by oath .If the search is conducted without a search warrant , the evidence is subject to the exclusionary rule .
text3: Proof does not need to be signed and sworn to in order to be admissible in court, despite what many people believe. Defense attorneys refer to the defendant's handwritten notebook as a "DIY confessional" because it is considered admissible proof without needing to be signed and sworn to. A defense attorney could also use the defendant's electronic communications, such as emails and text messages, as evidence in their case. Testimony does not need to be signed and sworn to in order to be considered admissible evidence. Testimony can be considered admissible evidence even without being signed and sworn to. Evidence can either confirm or disprove something and is subject to laws that may exclude it. The Fourth Amendment protects people from unreasonable searches and seizures, requiring warrants to be issued based on probable cause and specifically describing the place and items to be seized. Therefore, a search warrant must be supported by probable cause and sworn to in order to be obtained. If the search is done without a warrant, the evidence may be excluded based on the exclusionary rule.

text1:
In 1917, the Senate reformed its rules so that the majority party would not have to appeal to 60 votes to end debate on a bill. The change enabled the use of a cloture petition. The rule permits any Senator to petition the Chair to end debate at any time, by filing a cloture petition. The petition may be filed on any legislative matter on the Senate Calendar, except that a petition may not be filed under Rule XXII unless there has been an interruption of the business of the Senate by a Senator, by a call of the Senate, or by an appeal from a ruling of the Chair. In such cases, if two-thirds of the Senators present and voting vote in the affirmative, debate is terminated immediately. If not, the Senate continues to debate.
Q: In this time of political polarization, why don’t both parties agree to end the filibuster?
A: The reality is that, as in the US House, the majority party in the Senate does have the power to pass most things, including bills that would end the filibuster. In fact, in 2005, Senate Republicans did just that, doing away with filibusters on judicial nominations and an update to the Federal Communications Act.  In addition, in 2013, Senator Harry Reid invoked Rule XIV, and the so-called nuclear option, to end filibusters on presidential nominations.

The shift allowed the using of a cloture request .The rule allows any Senator to request the Chair to end debate at any time , by filing a cloture request . The request may be filed on any legislative matter on the Senate Calendar , except that a petition might not be filed under Rule XXII unless there has been an interruption of the business of the Senate by a Senator , by a call of the Senate , or by an appeal from a ruling of the Chair .In such cases , if two - thirds of the Senators present and voting voting in the affirmative , debate is terminated immediately . If not , the Senate continues to debate .Q : In this time of political polarization , why don ’ t both parties agree to end the filibuster ? In addition , in 2013 , Senator Harry Reid invoked Rule XIV , and the so - called nuclear option , to end filibusters on presidential nominations .

The rule change enabled Senators to request the Chair to end debate by filing a cloture request at any time. A cloture request can be filed for any legislative issue on the Senate Calendar, but only after there has been a disruption in Senate business. If two-thirds of Senators present and voting vote in favor, debate is immediately ended in such situations. If the cloture request is not approved, the Senate will continue debating. Why don't both parties come to a consensus to eliminate the filibuster during this era of political division? Why don't both parties agree to get rid of the filibuster in this politically divided era? Just like in the House of Representatives, the majority party in the Senate has the ability to pass most legislation, especially bills that would eliminate the filibuster. In 2005, Senate Republicans eliminated filibusters on judicial nominations and updated the Federal Communications Act. Furthermore, Senator Harry Reid utilized Rule XIV in 2013 to eliminate filibusters on presidential nominations through the nuclear option.

text1:
Disputing a Charge
Chargeback disputing is a process by which a customer’s bank, also known as the issuing bank, disputes a charge by the customer’s credit or debit card issuer. This process involves sending a “chargeback” to the merchant’s bank, the “acquiring bank”, with a reason code that explains the reason for the chargeback. The reason code is an important part of the dispute process because it allows the acquiring bank to know why the transaction was being disputed. The acquiring bank will then investigate the dispute and provide the results to the merchant’s bank. If the acquiring bank determines that the chargeback was not legitimate, they may refund the money back to the customer or may require the customer to pay back the money to the merchant. However, if the acquiring bank determines that the chargeback was legitimate, they may require the merchant to pay back the money to the customer or may take other action, such as closing the merchant’s account.
How to Avoid Chargebacks?
Why should I be concerned about chargebacks? There are several reasons why chargebacks are of concern to merchants:
The cost of processing a chargeback transaction is higher than the cost of a regular transaction.
Chargebacks can be a sign of potential fraud and may require additional resources to investigate.
Chargebacks can be a sign of a consumer who is unhappy with their purchase, which could affect the merchant’s reputation and customer satisfaction.

This process involves sending a “ chargeback ” to the merchant ’ s bank , the “ acquiring bank ” , with a reason code that explains the reason for the chargeback .The reason code is an important part of the disagreement process because it allows the owning bank to guess why the transaction was being disputed . The acquiring bank will then investigate the disagreement and provide the results to the merchant ’ s bank .If the owning bank determines that the chargeback was not legitimate , they may refund the money back to the customer or may need the customer to pay back the money to the merchant . However , if the owning bank determines that the chargeback was legitimate , they may allow the merchant to pay back the money to the customer or may took other action , such as closing the merchant ’ s account .How to Avoid Chargebacks ? Why should I be worried about chargebacks ?There are several reasons why chargebacks are of worry to dealers : The cost of processing a chargeback deal is higher than the cost of a regular transaction . Chargebacks can be a sign of potential fraud and may need extra resources to probe .Chargebacks can be a sign of a consumer who is disappointed with their purchase , which could affect the merchant ’ s reputation and customer happiness .

The acquiring bank will look into the dispute and share the findings with the merchant's bank. If the bank finds that the chargeback was not valid, they may either reimburse the customer or require the customer to repay the merchant. If the customer's bank finds the chargeback to be valid, they may require the merchant to refund the money or take further action, such as closing the merchant's account. How can one prevent chargebacks? What is the importance of being concerned about chargebacks? Dealers are concerned about chargebacks because the cost of processing a chargeback transaction is higher than a regular transaction. Chargebacks can indicate possible fraud and may require additional investigation. They can also signal customer dissatisfaction with a purchase, impacting the reputation and satisfaction of the merchant.

Kyle Rittenhouse is a young man from Antioch, Illinois (near Chicago) who is on trial for killing two people and injuring one other during the protests in Kenosha, Wisconsin last year. Why is this a big deal? It’s partly because Rittenhouse has become a symbol for many different people. His supporters say he was protecting Kenosha during violent protests. Some think that he was a vigilante or even a murderer. For those who support him, it’s an issue of self-defense and using deadly force when you feel your life is in danger. Those who don’t think Rittenhouse should have killed anyone, point to the fact that he broke the law. Wisconsin law states that if you’re under 18 you cannot carry a gun if you’re not in military or law enforcement. That’s the law Rittenhouse broke. The case is a big deal because there are a lot of emotions around it.

A: So there are a few issues. First, the main question is whether he shot in self-defense or if he just killed people. This is a legal issue that will require a jury to decide. But even outside of the legal issues, the biggest issue with the case is that Rittenhouse became an icon for some. Supporters were sending him money for his legal defense.

text1:
In the 1960s, a magazine called Life featured a cover story entitled “The Pot Paper” on the growing trend of people smoking marijuana. It was an article praising the merits of marijuana and the idea of legalizing the drug. You could get a sense that the tide was changing, but by the end of the 1960s, the tide had changed in the opposite direction. The War on Drugs was declared by President Richard Nixon and marijuana prohibition had officially become the law of the land. Ever since that time, we have been engaged in a conflict over the relative harms of two substances: Marijuana and tobacco. I am not here to convince you that marijuana is less harmful than cigarettes, but I think there is sufficient evidence to support the idea that we could have made both substances illegal in 1970. With regards to smoking marijuana, I think that the greatest harms of smoking the drug are the harms associated with using it on a regular basis (think to avoid school or work or relationships). When we are talking about the harms of smoking marijuana, we are talking about those harms. We need to be more clear about the nature of the harms. A valid argument to ban marijuana would need to be based upon these types of harms, and it is not based upon its harms compared to the harms of cigarettes.
That being said, the actual harm of smoking marijuana is not well defined.

text1:
Generally, when you pay for a good or service, you own the good or service. We may grant you a license to use something that we created, but the license doesn’t give you ownership over the item. Unless you explicitly buy the right to use, copy, modify, or redistribute something, it’s not yours. If you are not sure if something is yours, don’t assume.
Q: Isn’t taking ownership kind of like stealing?
A: Kind of. But the difference between stealing a candy bar from the store and copying someone else’s music is kind of like the difference between passive eavesdropping and making copies of a private conversation. For example, if you are chatting with a friend and someone secretly records your conversation, that person has broken the law unless you give them permission to do so. Recording the conversation without your knowledge or permission is a violation of your privacy.
Copying someone else’s work without permission can violate your copyright.
Q: Isn’t the law about copyrights only enforced in the U.S.?
A: Generally speaking, a copyrighted work is considered protected under United States Copyright law when it is created, regardless of where it is created. But, just because something is copyrighted in the U.S., it doesn’t mean that other countries consider it copyrighted.
Q: Can you tell me about the DMCA?
A: The Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) was passed in 1998.

text1:
Because they have never encountered people who actually disagree with them.
Reality can be... unpleasant for some people.
Modern western societies (and the anglo-saxon and spanish world in general) have the perfect mechanism to contain these kind of emigrants: they don't do emigration. They do re-immigration instead.
The last time a majority of people openly and freely emigrated out of their country and actually did it, was back in the XVIII century. Nowadays they just go to another european state. Hell, they don't even need a plane, because they can just drive their car and overstay their visas.
They don't have to cross the ocean, they don't have to face dying in the desert and they don't need visas. They get to stay with all their wealth and even take welfare benefits from the host countries. So all the people who do emigrate are either the poor ones who go somewhere far away (thus adding to the problem in a different place) or the super rich ones who either bribe their way out or leave for some island somewhere. If they are rich enough to bribe their way out, then no other method of government control is going to matter. And if they are not rich enough, they just will go somewhere else to live as an expat.
Ever heard of the Global Wealth Migration Index? It tracks the number of millionaires moving to a specific country in a specific period of time.

They are more likely to return to their home country rather than emigrate. Currently, they simply travel to another European country without needing a plane, as they can drive their car and overstay their visas. They can stay without crossing the ocean, facing dangers in the desert, or needing visas, while also receiving welfare payments from the host states. Therefore, those who emigrate are either impoverished individuals relocating to distant locations or affluent individuals who use bribery or move to secluded islands. If they have enough money to bribe officials, then government regulations will not be effective. If they lack wealth, they will simply relocate to another country as an expatriate. Are you familiar with the Global Wealth Migration Index? It tracks the amount of wealthy individuals relocating to a specific country within a specific timeframe.

text1:
- Age of consent is the legal age when a person can choose to do something for themself.  Once the age of consent is met, it is not longer considered illegal for the person to do something.
Q: - What is “caring adult” or “mature minor” status?
A: - This is when a minor is considered old enough and mature enough to make a decision regarding their healthcare.  This is based on what the medical professional believes is appropriate at the time of decision.
Q: - What is “giving consent”?
A: - This means that a person can make the decision about whether or not to undergo treatment.  The person giving consent is making the decision that it is in their best interest and is the right thing for them.
Q: - Can minors consent to their own medical treatment without the consent of their parent or legal guardian?
A: - Yes.  California minors are able to consent to their own medical treatment as long as they are at least 12 years old.  Minors 12 years old and older can consent to treatment for sexually transmitted infections (STI) and pregnancy related care.  If the minor is under 12 years old, they will require a parent or legal guardian to give consent.
Q: - Can parents consent to medical treatment for their minor child without the child’s consent?
A: - Yes.  Parents are able to give consent for their child for any medical treatment or procedure.

Because humans tend to notice the stench of poisonous gases. Therefore, they are detected and clogging gas masks are used. On the other hand, there is no reason for inmates to know that inert gases are being pumped into a room. Consequently, they are easy to detect. For more, see the following:
A process called "gas nitrification" neutralizes noxious elements in blood and other tissues, turning them into nitrogen. In a gas chamber, the inert gas has to be compressed to eight times its normal atmospheric pressure, so that the chamber's decompression door can be quickly opened in the event of an emergency. The inmates in the gas chamber must be free to escape the enclosure in case something goes wrong. The difference between decriminalisation and making it legal is simple. If you make it legal, you allow someone to use it openly. If you decriminalise it, they can still get punished for using it. It is just that they are punished in a way that doesn’t allow the stigma to destroy them completely. This way, the rest of society doesn’t reject them, so there is less harm to the person using it. As far as the person using it is concerned, there is not really a difference between the two, as it means they are allowed to use it. However, decriminalisation is far better for the community, as it keeps some order while allowing society to keep moving forward.
Q: So, it’s an improvement on what we have now, then?
A: Yes. It is an improvement on what we have now, but as always, you can do better.

A: Absolutely. Instead of just decriminalising something that is useful and essential for people, we can decriminalise a whole bunch of things. We can make it possible for people to do anything they want without fear of punishment, provided that their actions are not violent or aggressive.

text1:
why we don't use a lie detector for all crimes?
Q: What would be the problem?
A: There's no proof that people will actually tell the truth.
And while the polygraph may prove that they are lying, there is also no way to tell if they are lying about the lie or about the truth.
Either way, even if they are telling the truth, it doesn't always mean that they're telling the whole truth, or that what they are saying is true.
Q: So the technology isn't always reliable?
A: It is just as reliable as any other system of proof. It all depends on the information provided, and how reliable that information is.
This information could be based on witnesses statements, or even a confession.
A confession is the most reliable proof a criminal can give, however it is up to the judge and the jury to determine whether or not it is trustworthy. For example, a person confessing to a crime may later claim that they were beaten by police officers, or had been threatened by someone else in order to admit to the crime.
Q: What if the police get the confession?
A: The confession is still just as unreliable. The police may have used any number of methods to get the confession. The person may have been coerced into giving it by officers who were under pressure to close the case. The person may have been subjected to many hours of questioning without being informed of their rights.

If someone gives their confidence to a police officer or lawyer, they are expecting it to remain private and for the information given not to be used for another purpose. The exception is when you have ‘dual capacity’, for example, when you are an officer investigating a crime and at the same time working as a lawyer to represent a client. In these cases, you have to make clear to the other party that you have a dual role and not give advice based on what you know from your police role. Get legal advice from a qualified lawyer.

text1:
Civil asset forfeiture proceedings in Michigan are now less of a deterrent. In June, Gov. Rick Snyder signed bills making Michigan a little more free from the threat of property seizures and forfeiture.
However, police still can seize the property of people who haven't been convicted of a crime, under the legislation.
Former Michigan State Police Lt. David Schmiedicke of Holland said that forfeiture is a tool the police department used on occasion. He is a member of the forfeiture unit of the Ottawa County Sheriff's Office.
Ottawa County Sheriff's Deputy Nick Grooters, who is assigned to the forfeiture unit, said the Sheriff's Office seized more than $25,000 from one person who pleaded guilty to possession of methamphetamine, under state guidelines.
Grooters said the money was forfeited through the victim's forfeiture fund, which allows victims of a crime to collect money from the criminal activity.
The victim's forfeiture fund is not forfeited automatically if a plea deal is reached, Schmiedicke said. It requires a hearing.
State Rep. Gary Glenn, R-Midland, said he was pleased when Snyder signed the bills. "This is not perfect legislation, but it is a significant step toward correcting a significant injustice. Many who support asset forfeiture believe we went too far, (while) those opposed believe we didn't go far enough. But we can always review the issue again to address concerns in future legislation.

But we can always study the issue again to address concerns in future laws .

David Schmiedicke from Holland mentioned that the police department occasionally utilizes forfeiture as a tactic. The structure is like this: by leaving the determination to the individual, with the Texas Legislature funding the private parties to do the legal work and bear the financial risk of pursuing the claims against abortionists who do not follow the law. In this way, if the federal courts knock down one provision of the law, another provision can be put in place. If the Legislature or the funders run out of money to pay for all the cases, new legislation can be passed to appropriate more funds. text1:
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are separate agencies that focus on different aspects of the safety of medical devices.
A: The FDA is the regulatory agency responsible for reviewing the safety and effectiveness of medical devices sold in the U.S. The FDA regulates medical devices through pre-market review and inspections. The FDA maintains a database of medical devices to track recalls.
A: The FDA premarket approval process ensures that the device will safely and effectively perform its intended use before it is sold.
The FDA closely monitors the safety of devices it has cleared for marketing, ensuring the devices continue to meet the safety and effectiveness requirements of the law.
Manufacturers and users of medical devices report problems to the FDA through the MedWatch program. When problems are reported, the FDA will take action to protect the public if the agency has information that indicates that a medical device may have harmed someone. It can remove the device from the market, order corrections or changes to the device's labeling or packaging, or issue public communications to consumers and health care professionals about problems with the device.
A: The FDA also regulates medical devices through a fast-track process, which the FDA uses to streamline the review and marketing of medical devices intended for patients with serious or life-threatening diseases or conditions. This process applies to certain medical devices intended for these types of patients. Devices considered to be of low to moderate risk, such as contact lenses and adhesive bandages, do not require premarket approval.

A : The FDA additionally regulates health equipment through a speed - track process , which the FDA uses to streamline the review and selling of health technologies intended for patients with major or life - threatening illness or circumstances .This process applies to many medical devices meant for these kinds of patients . text1:
Dissolving parliament means appointing a new parliament. Dissolving government means making new ministries.
Q: What happens when a government dissolves itself?
A: A lot of work.
Q: Which countries have dissolved their government?
A: There are many countries. Sometimes they dissolve for fun, and sometimes they're serious.
Q: What are their names?
A: Belarus (in 1994), Brazil (1992), Burkina Faso (2000), Canada (1958), Fiji (1977), Gambia (1994), Ghana (1969), Guatemala (1985), Guinea-Bissau (1998), Indonesia (1966), Liberia (1980), Niger (2010), Sierra Leone (1992), Tunisia (2011), Trinidad and Tobago (1986), Turkey (2007) and Uganda (1995).
Q: But what's their motive?
A: Probably getting more important than the former government.
Q: So, if they're not serious, why don't they dissolve the parliament too?
A: Because they can't. Only the head of state can do that.

Georgia state law allows for anyone who commits an "overt act" during the commission of a felony to be charged as an accomplice.
In Bryan's case, the overt act was the beating death of Ahmaud Arbery at the hands of Gregory McMichael and Travis McMichael in a neighborhood near Brunswick, Ga. Travis McMichael, the younger of the two, shot Arbery with a shotgun.
Bryan and the McMichaels have all been charged with felony murder and a separate charge of aggravated assault.
Bryan can also be charged with criminal attempt to commit false imprisonment, a misdemeanor under Georgia law. At a preliminary hearing, prosecutors presented evidence that Bryan struck Arbery while the McMichaels held him down, reports the Atlanta Journal-Constitution. A judge will decide whether there's enough evidence to send the case to a grand jury.
Bryan's lawyer, Kevin Gough, is arguing the 50-year-old did not participate in any crime, despite Bryan's acknowledgement that he helped the McMichaels apprehend Arbery, reports USA Today.
Bryan's trial is slated for November. 
Arbery's family lawyers have filed a lawsuit against Bryan, the McMichaels and several law enforcement officials for violating Arbery's civil rights.
Arbery was a Black man who lived in Brunswick and frequently jogged in his neighborhood. On Feb.

Q: If an accident or something happens that you get charged with it, and you did not do it, how do you find a lawyer to defend you?
A: I would look for a member of the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers in your area.
Q: What is the difference between plea bargain and being held guilty at a jury trial?
A: In a plea bargain, you admit to something and, in exchange, the prosecutor might agree to a lesser offense or a lesser charge or a lesser penalty. In a jury trial, a group of your peers determines whether you are guilty or not.
Q: Is plea bargaining allowed in the state of Florida for driving under the influence of alcohol?
A: Yes, but only if you are not on probation, you were not a defendant in an earlier DUI offense within 10 years, and if your blood alcohol content was below 0.15%.
Q: How do I fight a court order that states that I have to pay money to my son's mother?
A: Talk to a Florida family law lawyer about how to work with the court to meet your obligations as a parent.
Q: What does a plea deal include in a domestic battery case?
A: They will offer a time period of probation with fines and community service hours.

text1:
Prison sentences of consecutive life terms require that a criminal be convicted of two different, and especially serious, crimes, and that the crimes are connected to each other.
All states, including the District of Columbia, and the federal government allow consecutive life sentences. Some states allow for life sentences in the aggregate, or "stacking," meaning that a sentence for a crime can be added to any sentences already received.
Thirty-nine states allow for consecutive life sentences. The method used for consecutive sentences can vary among these states.
When multiple convictions are for crimes committed at the same time, such as a joint robbery, they are called concurrent sentences. The most common consecutive sentences are murders committed at different times, especially if the murders are connected.
In the federal system and in a majority of states, consecutive sentences can only be imposed by a jury, or by the judge in federal court. The amount of time involved can range from 25 years to the remainder of the convict's life. The length of a sentence depends on the seriousness of the crime committed.
In cases involving the murders of multiple victims, the convict might be sentenced to two life sentences, with the murder of one victim counted as one and the other as a second murder. In addition to a life sentence for murder, the same convict could receive additional consecutive sentences for other charges, such as kidnapping or sexual assault, even if these crimes were committed before the murder.

Every state, including DC, and the federal government permit consecutive life sentences, with some states allowing for sentences to be stacked on top of each other. Thirty-nine states permit consecutive life sentences, with the specific method for imposing these sentences differing among them. Concurrent convictions are when multiple crimes are committed simultaneously, like a joint robbery, while consecutive sentences are typically for murders committed at different times, especially if they are related. I really can’t tl;dr the back story, but I can summarize a bit.
Kyle Rittenhouse is a white man who is 17 years old. He showed up at a Black Lives Matter rally on August 25, 2020. He said he was there to “protect property”. He brought a rifle. He said he was a medic. He is a paramedic-in-training, not an actual medical professional, and there is no evidence he had ever given any actual aid at any fire or any place where people were sick or injured. Someone at the rally told police Rittenhouse was armed, but no one followed that up with anything and Rittenhouse was left there with his rifle.
A Black man named Joe Rosenbaum was at the rally. Rosenbaum was an outspoken, eccentric dude, and he seems to have had a history of getting himself in trouble at protests. He had not been listening to any speeches about social injustice; he had been off to the side having a public confrontation with other protesters. His father had died, but he was having issues with a girlfriend or an ex, and was in the middle of a custody battle with her about their child. Rosenbaum was visibly drunk at the rally.
The police had withdrawn. The scene devolved into a mass of fighting people. Rosenbaum grabbed Rittenhouse’s gun. He was shot by Rittenhouse. One witness to the shooting says Rosenbaum had a knife in his hand at the time.

text1:
The short answer is that the court can put a lien on the defendant's property. While a judgment lien only secures money that the defendant has currently or which might come into their hands, an execution lien secures all the defendant's property both current and potential.
The plaintiff in a civil suit is entitled to be awarded their judgment (a certain amount of money), but they aren't entitled to the defendant's property unless and until the court orders the money paid. Therefore, in order to secure their right to payment, they must ask the court for something called a writ of execution. (Note: The process of securing payment from a judgment debtor in California is a very simple and streamlined process and doesn't require an attorney or anything but the most basic paperwork.)
Q: Can the court use an execution lien to take possession of the defendant's property?
A: No, the court is not allowed to take possession of the defendant's property, but they are entitled to seize the defendant's non-exempt property to sell. If the defendant owns his or her home, the court is entitled to seize any non-exempt equity that may be present. An important caveat to this is that if the home is subject to a second deed of trust, the court must seek the permission of the first lender to sell the property and apply the proceeds to the judgment, because the first deed of trust is senior to the second one.
text2: The short answer is that the court can put a lien on the defendant ' s estate . While a decision lien only secures cash that the defendant has currently or which would go into their hands , an execution lien secures all the defendant ' s estate both current and potential .The plaintiff in a civil suit is entitled to be awarded their verdict ( a certain quantity of money ) , but they aren ' t entitled to the defendant ' s estate unless and until the court orders the money paid . Therefore , in order to secure their right to pay , they must ask the court for something termed a writ of execution .( Note : The method of securing payment from a judgment debtor in California is a very simple and streamlined process and doesn ' t require an lawyer or anything but the most basic documents . ) Q : Can the court utilize an execution lien to take possession of the defendant ' s estate ?A : No , the court is not allowed to take possession of the defendant ' s estate , but they are entitled to seize the defendant ' s non - exempt land to sell . If the defendant owns his or her home , the court is entitled to seize any non - exempt equity that might be present .An key caveat to this is that if the home is subject to a second deed of trust , the court must seek the authorization of the first lender to sell the property and apply the profits to the judgment , because the first deed of trust is senior to the second one .
text3: In short, the court has the ability to place a lien on the defendant's estate. An execution lien secures all of the defendant's current and potential estate, while a decision lien only secures cash that the defendant currently has or would receive. Hence, they need to request a writ of execution from the court to ensure they receive payment. Securing payment from a judgment debtor in California is a straightforward process that does not require a lawyer or complex documents. Can the court use an execution lien to seize the defendant's assets? Can the court use an execution lien to seize the defendant's assets? The court cannot take ownership of the defendant's estate, but they can seize the defendant's non-exempt property for sale. If the defendant owns a home, the court can seize any non-exempt equity that may be available. If the defendant's home has a second deed of trust, the court needs approval from the first lender to sell the property and use the proceeds to pay off the judgment, as the first deed of trust takes precedence over the second.

text1:
Great question. First and foremost, every young man is required to register with the Selective Service System if he is a citizen, permanent resident, undocumented resident, non-citizen or any person residing in the United States, including men and boys from the age of 18 and up. Those required to register who are eligible for conscription are also required to be physically qualified for service, otherwise they can receive a deferment. A deferment can be granted due to a person being:
Over the age of 26 and unmarried
Selected for OCS, JAG, or JROTC
Masters or doctors in certain scientific fields
In certain situations, a person may receive a deferment of a draft call and then may be called up for service, even if their deferment would allow them to not be in the military by the time of their draft call. This is because they will be responsible to serve the full term of service (length of time the draft lasts, usually two years, with the option to stay in for another six).

text1:
When there is a court order, it means there is a judge who has authority over the matter. Failure to comply with that order means you are in contempt of court. In a civil contempt of court, you can be jailed, for example, in a child support matter. In a criminal contempt of court, the judge is not going to treat it lightly.
Q: What happens if you can't afford a lawyer for a criminal matter?
A: If you cannot afford a lawyer in criminal cases, a judge will appoint a lawyer for you. In almost every criminal case that is prosecuted, the case is prosecuted by a government employee. That person has to do it as part of their job, and as such they cannot charge money for the service.
Q: What do you need to do in a criminal case to prove innocence?
A: You have to have sufficient evidence that will disprove the charge against you beyond a reasonable doubt. It is basically the same burden of proof as in a civil case, and it's a lot of evidence to produce.
Q: If you've been convicted of a crime and now you're charged with a crime again, can they raise the new conviction as a reason for jailing you?
A: Yes. Once you've been convicted of a crime, if you have to go before a judge for something you will most likely be remanded to jail.

text1:
MIRRORED LEATHER BELTS
The 1977 movie "Smokey and the Bandit" featured a car chase in which Sheriff Buford T. Justice's (Sorrell Booke) bullet-shattered hubcaps are replaced with "spare hubcaps" kept in the trunk. In real life, detectives didn't have to be quite so resourceful: Before computers were developed to store such information, police officials would bring the evidence to the main jail in a town and read them into a logbook. They also could find a copy of the records in other law enforcement offices around the country.
Law enforcement would often request a picture or a fingerprint card and then the crime laboratory or the police department they were working with would submit the data to the FBI. In some instances, a detective would put in a phone call to a local office of the FBI to request fingerprint cards for a suspect in order to have that person's prints analyzed.
Q: How is animal cruelty investigated?
A: VIDEO AND WEBSITES
It's more difficult to investigate animal cruelty, since animal abusers often operate in secret and victimized animals may not be able to speak for themselves. Some counties use a specially trained dog to locate dead animals or traces of blood at a scene, and patrol deputies may be specially trained to recognize signs of animal abuse.
Some animal shelters have taken on the job of investigating animal cruelty.

Did the U.S. declare a draft for Vietnam?
The draft existed for Vietnam. There was an induction center for Vietnam in each state, as there had been for the two world wars. The difference, however, was that in WW2 and the Korean War, Congress had voted to make every man of a certain age in the country liable for service in the armed forces. During Vietnam, a number of times, the age was increased, but no actual declaration was made to cover the whole country. It was more like a running expansion of liability.

The phrase expresses the idea that those who supply the drugs are ultimately the ones who are doing more harm. This is because it is the supply of drugs which is a key part of the problem, not merely the demand.
In other words, it is not enough to simply limit the drug addicts from obtaining drugs. Those who supply the drugs are not simply supplying an innocuous product; they are the source of the harm that the addicts ultimately inflict on themselves.

text1:
For about 30 years—roughly from 1930 to 1960—organized crime in the United States was dominated by four families: the Buffalo mob, the Chicago outfit, the New Orleans mob, and the New York family (the latter headed by Joseph Bonanno, Carlo Gambino, and Joseph Magliocco until 1957, when they were succeeded by Charles “Lucky” Luciano and Vito Genovese). Throughout that period, the New York family was regarded as the leader among the families, which gave it unique opportunities to affect organized crime and labor rackets across the country.
Indeed, one of the defining characteristics of the New York family was its interest in labor unions. The union rackets were essential to organized crime in the 1930s, 1940s, and 1950s, as they provided a relatively secure source of income to supplement the illegal enterprises of gambling, prostitution, loan-sharking, and so forth.
And within the union rackets, the Teamsters Union was regarded as one of the most lucrative targets. In New York, for instance, the Teamsters Union Local 807 was a subunion of 4,000 workers engaged in making express deliveries, and was managed by Dominick “Big Dom” Bova.
text2: For about 30 years — approximately from 1930 to 1960 — organized crime in the United States was dominated by four families : the Buffalo mob , the Chicago outfit , the New Orleans gang , and the New York family ( the latter headed by Joseph Bonanno , Carlo Gambino , and Joseph Magliocco until 1957 , when they were replaced by Charles “ Lucky ” Luciano and Vito Genovese ) . Throughout that period , the New York family was considered as the leader among the families , which gave it distinct options to affect organized criminals and labor rackets across the nation .Indeed , one of the important characteristics of the New York family was its interest in labor unions . The union rackets were vital to organized criminals in the 1930s , 1940s , and 1950s , as they offered a fairly stable source of revenue to supplement the illegal businesses of gambling , prostitution , loan - sharking , and so forth .And within the union rackets , the Teamsters Union was considered as one of the most prestigious targets . In New York , for instance , the Teamsters Union Local 807 was a subunion of 4 , 000 workers engaged in making express deliveries , and was run by Dominick “ Big Dom ” Bova .
text3: From around 1930 to 1960, four families controlled organized crime in the United States: the Buffalo mob, the Chicago outfit, the New Orleans gang, and the New York family. During that time, the New York family was seen as the most powerful among the families, allowing them to influence organized crime and labor rackets nationwide. Their focus on labor unions was a key aspect of their operations. During the 1930s, 1940s, and 1950s, organized crime relied on union rackets for consistent income to support their illegal activities like gambling, prostitution, and loan-sharking. The Teamsters Union was a particularly coveted target within these rackets. Dominick "Big Dom" Bova was in charge of the Teamsters Union Local 807 in New York, which consisted of 4,000 workers involved in express deliveries.

A: Yes, plea bargains are very important for police work because it’s hard to identify a case that will lead to a conviction. Police have to consider the limited resources and the nature of the crime, and they have to make sure it’s the most appropriate case to be pursued.

A: A witness is always more credible if you’ve been able to interview them many times. Trust is key, so police officers have to be persistent. They have to go back and forth until you get to the point where they say what happened.

A: To make the community feel comfortable and safe. That can be done in a number of ways, including officers walking the streets, or being friendly with people on the street. Officers can also do outreach programs with the community.

A: There are three reasons why police officers have to be trained in a university setting.

text1:
It is important to have precedent in the justice system because without it the rules would constantly be changing and no one would know the law of the land. It is important to have a common basis of knowledge about what the law is so that all people know what to expect when they are under the law. It would also be very unfair if some people had different rulings for the same crime. Having precedent helps a community feel safer because they know what to expect if they are in a situation that requires the justice system. For example, a person who was given 10 years for murder and is released on parole after 5 years would not be as likely to re-offend if he or she knew that the judge could have given a life sentence. Precedent is important because it allows people to know the rules of their community without having to re-learn them over and over again.
  1. What is a precedent and how is it important in our system of government? It is important because precedent is used to determine an appropriate course of action for a situation that is similar to one that the government has already encountered. For example, a number of decisions in the United States Supreme Court decisions have established the precedent that it is unconstitutional for the government to impose a tax for what is essentially a license to exercise a Constitutional right (e.g., freedom of speech, bearing arms, etc.).

If a lawyer wants to be involved in litigation, a lawyer's personal integrity and ethics become so much more essential to success. This is because, if he acts for himself, all of his acts are subject to challenge by his opponent, who could be a forensic magician.
The following case is unusual and rare, but it illustrates this. In 1958, Alfred Montague represented himself before Mr. Justice Gange in a contempt of court case, in London's High Court.
He defended a point of law, a narrow question, but a point of great significance to Mr. Montague: he sought to avoid bankruptcy. He took on the role of his own counsel.
The court found him guilty of the contempt of court. The judge did not question Mr. Montague's law, but he pointed out that Mr. Montague had recklessly infringed rules of procedure.
Mr. Montague was outraged. He was willing to argue the law but not the procedure. He was mistaken and he knew it.
He claimed that the judge had a duty to consider the merit of his case, in addition to his abuse of procedure. And he thought it was reasonable for him to rely on his own understanding of the law and to avoid the pitfalls of the rules of procedure.
There was a further and crushing irony in Mr. Montague's hubris. He insisted that the judge was being unreasonable in declining to rule on the merits. In his view, Mr.

text1:
because it's hard to change the culture of prisons quickly enough.
I would have to admit that having the status of'sex offender' makes rehabilitation very hard. If not impossible. For most of my life my name and photo have been on the Sex Offenders' Register and anyone is allowed to look at it. Is it any wonder that when, in the eyes of the law, I am a leper, I have a tendency to avoid contact with other people?
There is a loophole in the rules that allows people to spend their sentence in prison and after their release not have their name on the register if their offending history is quite old. However, for a different reason, I wasn't eligible for that.
The irony of all of this is that it doesn't matter whether you offend or not once you're released from prison - as soon as you get out of the prison gates, your life is considered less valuable to the public.
This is how you explain the sexual violence perpetrated by prisoners against prisoners and prisoners against prison staff. When someone leaves their cell and ends up in trouble, they can be sent to a segregated unit. To the 'Special Observation Unit' (SOU) as it is called.
