The irony of all of this is that it doesn ' t matter whether you offend or not once you ' re released from jail - as quickly as you go out of the prison gates , your life is deemed less valuable to the public .This is how you explain the sexual violence perpetrated by prisoners against prisoners and prisoners against jail staff . When anyone exits their cell and ends up in trouble , they can be transferred to a segregated unit .To the ' Special Observation Unit ' ( SOU ) as it is known .
text3: Changing the culture of prisons rapidly is difficult. Admitting that being labeled a 'sex offender' greatly hinders rehabilitation. It can be challenging, but it is achievable. My name and photo have been on the Sex Offenders' Register for most of my life, and it is visible to anyone. Is it surprising that I avoid contact with others when I am seen as an outcast by the law? Not being eligible for a loophole that allows someone to avoid being on the Sex Offenders' Register after their release due to the age of their offending history. Upon release from prison, your worth to society diminishes regardless of whether you commit another offense, leading to a cycle of sexual violence within the prison system. If someone gets into trouble outside of their cell, they may be moved to a separate unit. The Special Observation Unit, also known as the SOU.

text1:
In theory, naturalization laws should be treated as if they are written on tablets of stone. Since the first arrival of Europeans in the New World, countries have developed naturalization laws to define, in a sense, the political and social makeup of their citizens.
Perhaps no other aspect of nationality law is more codified, more steeped in precedent, and more sacrosanct than that of naturalization. And yet, almost as if to remind us that the sovereignty of nations is tenuous, and at times fickle, naturalization laws come and go, change and shift, over time. As an example, think back to the Naturalization Act of 1790, which restricted naturalization to free white persons only. Or to the Hart-Celler Act of 1965, which by ending the discriminatory quota system ended decades of legislation rooted in the fiction that ethnic and racial minorities should be excluded from naturalization. From one side of history to the other, laws governing who qualifies as a citizen of the United States have shifted. The same, in fact, is true of the naturalization laws of many other countries. What, then, has led to these changes in naturalization policy?
In recent years, in particular, there has been increasing interest in how and why naturalization laws are revised and changed.
text2: In theory , naturalization laws should be treated as if they are written on tablets of stone . Since the first arrival of Europeans in the New World , states have developed naturalization laws to define , in a sense , the political and social makeup of their residents .Perhaps no other aspect of citizenship law is more codified , more steeped in precedent , and more sacrosanct than that of naturalization . And yet , almost as if to remind us that the sovereignty of states is tenuous , and at times fickle , naturalization laws come and goes , shift and shift , over time .As an instance , think back to the Naturalization Act of 1790 , which restricted naturalization to free white persons only . Or to the Hart - Celler Act of 1965 , which by closing the discriminatory quota system stopped decades of legislation rooted in the fantasy that ethnic and racial minorities should be excluded from naturalization .From one side of history to the other , laws controlling who qualifies as a resident of the United States have shifted . The same , in reality , is true of the naturalization laws of several other countries .What , then , has led to these changes in naturalization policy ? In recent years , in particular , there has been growing interest in how and why naturalization laws are revised and changed .
text3: Naturalization laws should be considered as unchangeable. States have created naturalization laws to shape the political and social composition of their residents since Europeans first arrived in the New World. Naturalization laws are the most established and revered aspect of citizenship law. Despite the perception of naturalization laws as unchangeable, they actually fluctuate and evolve over time, as demonstrated by the Naturalization Act of 1790. The Hart-Celler Act of 1965 put an end to the discriminatory quota system that had been in place for decades, challenging the belief that ethnic and racial minorities should be excluded from naturalization. Over time, laws determining who can be a resident of the United States have changed. What has caused changes in naturalization policy in other countries as well? Recently, there has been an increasing focus on the reasons behind the revision and alteration of naturalization laws.

text1:
Abortion providers can't receive “remuneration” for the remains of aborted fetuses.
Exemptions exist for a physician providing abortion services and for other health care workers, such as a nurse, midwife or paramedic. In addition, hospitals, certain ambulance services, research laboratories, medical schools, funeral homes and certain medical supply providers also are exempted from the law.

text1: Let’s start with this: Words are generally not speech. Saying “shut up” is not the same as “shut up” in writing. Because of the fleeting nature of “saying” in public or on the radio, a line such as “You’re a jackass” does not have the same potential to damage a person’s reputation as would the written equivalent. It’s also not the same as writing a letter to a magazine saying “You’re a jackass.” The written version has more permanence to it than the spoken or broadcast versions.
text2: Let ’ s start with this : Words are typically not speech . Saying “ shut up ” is not the same as “ shut up ” in writing .Because of the fleeting nature of “ saying ” in public or on the radio , a line such as “ You ’ re a jackass ” does not have the same potential to hurt a person ’ s notoriety as would the written equivalent . It ’ s also not the same as writing a note to a newspaper saying “ You ’ re a jackass . ” The written edition has more permanence to it than the spoken or televised versions .
text3: To begin, words are usually not spoken. Verbally telling someone to "shut up" is not as damaging as writing it down, as spoken words are fleeting and do not have the same lasting impact as written words. It is different from writing a letter to a newspaper calling someone a derogatory name. Written words have a longer-lasting impact compared to spoken or televised words.

Simple. Here's a list of one or more people that were each sentenced to life. Some of them have no parole, while some do. This depends on the state of the crime.
Mass Murderer :
The child killer Raymond Scott Jr. was sentenced to two life terms without parole. On September 29, 2002, he murdered his 6-year-old nephew, Gregory Allen Wells, and his 4-year-old son, Zeke. He killed them both with his pickup truck. He then proceeded to burn their bodies in the oven of a mobile home. He burned the two bodies to hide evidence of the murders. But he failed, and he was arrested. He was charged with two counts of capital murder for the deaths of Wells and Zeke and was also charged with the arson. He pled guilty to avoid the death penalty.
Retired Military :
Air Force Master Sergeant Elisha C. Anderson, 41, was sentenced to two consecutive life sentences, which means he'll never leave the cell. He pled guilty to involuntary manslaughter and fraud. While working at the Denver Air Force Base, he placed a faulty part on a C-130. It caused an engine failure, which killed seven people. This Air Force veteran will be eligible for parole in 2027 and 2028.
Officer :
Fred Davis was an Albuquerque police officer. In 1987, he shot a man in the back 10 times after the man had already been subdued.

text1: -The short answer is yes. Your being read your rights does not mean that the police have given up on getting evidence against you. Once they place you under arrest, they do not need to charge you for another 48 hours. There are instances when police agencies are very reluctant to charge a person after 48 hours after being arrested. These instances normally involve homicide or where there is evidence that the person being arrested is involved in drug trafficking, because it is very difficult to hold a person without any evidence after that time period. The 48 hours rule is an evidentiary rule. The general rule is that the police need to either charge you, or give you your property back, or release you, within 48 hours, absent exigent circumstances. The only exception is if the police can show that they are trying to get more evidence against you. The next step is to bring this evidence to a judge, but this cannot be done until after 48 hours. The judge has to consider the totality of the circumstances in determining if there is probable cause to charge you. This means that the judge has to determine if the evidence obtained by the police in the 48 hours after the arrest is substantial enough to justify the charge. Even if the judge agrees with the evidence, there is the question of whether or not it is admissible in court because of certain laws which say that evidence obtained in violation of certain rights may not be used against you in court.

There are cases when police organizations are very unwilling to charge a person after 48 hours after being arrested .These instances normally include murder or where there is evidence that the person being arrested is involved in drug trafficking , because it is very difficult to hold a person without any evidence after that time time . The 48 hours rule is an evidentiary rule .The general rule is that the authorities need to either charge you , or take you your property back , or release you , within 48 hours , absent exigent situations . The only exception is if the authorities can show that they are trying to getting more proof against you .The next step is to bring this evidence to a court , but this cannot be done until after 48 hours . The court has to consider the totality of the situations in determining if there is probable cause to charge you .This means that the judge has to determine if the evidence produced by the authorities in the 48 hours after the arrest is substantial enough to justify the charge . Even if the judge agrees with the proof , there is the question of whether or not it is admissible in court because of certain laws which say that information obtained in breach of certain rights might not be used against you in court .
text3: Yes, in short. Being informed of your rights does not indicate that the authorities have stopped trying to gather evidence against you. If they arrest you, they have 48 hours to charge you. In certain situations, police may hesitate to charge someone after the 48-hour window following their arrest, especially in cases involving murder or drug trafficking where evidence is scarce. Authorities must either charge you, return your property, or release you within 48 hours, unless there are urgent circumstances. The only exception is if authorities can demonstrate they are actively seeking additional evidence against you. The evidence must be presented in court, but this cannot happen until 48 hours have passed. The judge must assess all circumstances to decide if there is enough evidence within the 48-hour window to warrant charging you. The judge must also consider the admissibility of evidence in court, as information obtained in violation of certain rights may not be used against you.

If the judge is a real bully, she’ll actually haul you out of your home to punish you and your family and hand you to a debt collector who’ll take all your assets.
Candice Lomotey lives in a community of small wooden houses about the size of a small bedroom in the remote village of Wassa Akropong in Ghana, in West Africa.
She lives on a government pension of less than $300 a year. She cooks on an open fire and carries water by hand. She has no electricity, running water or other basic necessities that most people in the U.S. and Western Europe take for granted.
A few weeks ago, someone knocked on the door of her simple home and asked her for money she didn’t have.
Lomotey lives in a small settlement called Apremdo, about 100 miles north of Ghana’s capital, Accra, on the coast. She supports herself and her three children on her government pension, which amounts to about $6 a month.
So Lomotey offered to take the man back to the U.S. to help repay the loan.
The man said he’d send her more money. Lomotey has heard that promise from three others who have visited her in the past two months, promising to send her more money to help pay back the loans. Each of them, she said, has demanded the money in advance.

The European Commission's Directorate-General for Human Resources and Security (DG HR) recently changed its rules to introduce the concept of 'unlimited time off'. What does this mean for you and how is it different from parental leave, paid time off or sick leave? Is there an upper limit to 'unlimited time off'? Are there rules and what is the point of this change? This article will answer these questions for you.
What is 'unlimited time off'?
'Unlimited time off' is a term the Commission uses to describe a range of parental, family, other or special leave schemes. These schemes have existed for many years and include leave taken by, for example, parents to care for children under the age of 18 or leave for people caring for relatives or adults with disabilities. A Commission employee can take this kind of leave without having to give any reason. They do not have to give any notice either. They can also take it from time to time rather than all at once. The Commission supports its staff members who need time off to care for their families or for other reasons by giving them the possibility to use this leave. There is no limit on the number of days of 'unlimited time off' that you can take.
"Unlimited time off" means that you can take time off without asking for permission. You can take time off at short notice without giving a reason. You also have the option to take 'unlimited time off' in smaller chunks.

Two reasons, the law is too complicated and gives way too much leeway to bad-faith litigants, and because juries don’t want to, the judges don’t want to, and lawyers are ambivalent on the subject.
If I were to guess I’d say that 10-20% of lawsuits are filed with little or no hope of winning, often filed for spite, or out of anger. It costs the opposing party money to defend the lawsuit, but the typical resolution ends up in an out of court settlement that costs the litigant much less than a day in court. Settlements are private, and the amount the plaintiff gets for a bad faith lawsuit can be enormous. The net result is that bad faith litigants are getting an excellent deal, and the prevailing defendant often is out much more money than would have been necessary to pay the plaintiff, to have the plaintiff drop the lawsuit.
Consider the following scenario: Suppose the plaintiff is suing you for $1,000,000, but is a stone cold loser. You know this because 1) your lawyer has done a lot of research and knows the legal system better than you, and 2) your own experiences, though you yourself don’t know a lot about the law, has taught you a lot about how judges and juries behave. And you also know this: if you lose, you’ll lose all of your savings and be in dire straights.

text1:
DDoS (Distributed Denial of Service) attacks are used to disrupt the availability of a service by directing a large amount of traffic at the service.  A denial-of-service attack is one of the most common and easily carried out attacks.  The most common type of denial-of-service attacks are directed against Web servers.  This type of attack usually is a last resort for hackers, as it is the easiest attack to identify and block.  In fact, the term “attack” may not be the best term for a denial-of-service attack, as there is usually no hacker activity involved; the attack consists merely of directing a flood of traffic at a service.  DDoS attacks can include all of the following:
Harvesting your computer’s IP address
Internet packets can be made up of one or more segments of varying sizes and types.  Internet packets generally include the source and destination address and a size.
Overloading your system with too many requests or connections
Constantly sending HTTP request to your computer with no data
Sending large volumes of e-mail to your computer
Generating large volumes of ICMP messages
Creating a large volume of UDP packets
A Distributed Denial of Service attack is when a hacker sends messages to a large number of computers to get them to send a large amount of Internet packets to the victim's computer.  The victim's computer then receives so much Internet traffic that it cannot handle it and becomes unavailable to other users.

The most common type of denial-of-service attacks target Web servers and are easily executed. Denial-of-service attacks are often seen as a final option for hackers because they are easily detectable and can be blocked. In reality, these attacks involve simply flooding a service with traffic, without any actual hacking activity. DDoS threats may involve harvesting data from your laptop. Internet packets can consist of various segments in terms of size and type, typically containing source and destination addresses along with a size. “Save the Man” by David Campton takes you behind the courtroom doors and into the boardroom of law firms that are competing to win more cases. Follow two lead defense attorneys and two criminal defense partners as they share their strategies, experiences, and secrets of the profession. This is a drama about power, passion, and principles, and the challenges of achieving justice in the legal system.
It’s 10 minutes long and written by Marc Miller, Esq. starring four award-winning actors and directed by Dan O’Brien. Marc also stars as the fictional defense lawyer.
For legal risk managers, Don Palmer of the ARC Law Group has done a background report about legal ethics for lawyers at https://www.nvlawjournal.com/directors-note-ethics-of-plea-bargaining/amp/

The difference between second-degree murder and voluntary manslaughter in Texas is twofold. The first thing to know about both crimes is that there is no requirement that the person killed be intentionally killed by the defendant, unlike first-degree murder. In other words, in order to be guilty of first-degree murder in Texas, the State would have to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant intended to kill the person. That is not the case with second-degree murder. As for second-degree murder, there is no requirement that the defendant intended to kill. As long as the death occurs, the State has to prove only that the defendant committed an act that was criminally negligent or reckless. A reckless act is when a person’s action is a dangerous disregard for human life that resulted in someone being killed.
If you think about the phrase “reckless disregard,” you can see that it is broad. It is also subjective. That is, how dangerous would you think that a defendant’s action was to result in a death? Some people would not consider an action dangerous at all. How can a state determine that one person would consider the action reckless while another person would not? As you can see, recklessness is very subjective and will therefore be difficult to prove beyond a reasonable doubt. Recklessness can be proven by the defendant’s past history. If the defendant had been convicted of the same offense in the past, that would strengthen the State’s case.

That is not the case with second - degree killings .As for second - degree killings , there is no requirement that the defendant planned to kill . As long as the death occurs , the State has to prove only that the defendant committed an act that was criminally negligent or reckless .A reckless action is when a person ’ s action is a dangerous disregard for human life that resulted in someone being killed . That is , how hazardous would you believe that a defendant ’ s action was to result in a death ?Some persons might not consider an action hazardous at all . How can a state determine that one individual would regard the activity foolish while another someone would not ?As you can see , recklessness is very subjective and will consequently be harder to prove beyond a rational doubt . Recklessness can be verified by the defendant ’ s past history .If the defendant had been accused of the same offense in the past , that would reinforce the State ’ s case .
text3: There are two main distinctions between second-degree killing and voluntary manslaughter in Texas. In Texas, it is important to note that first-degree murder requires proof of intent to kill, unlike second-degree murder and voluntary manslaughter. Second-degree killings do not require proof of intent to kill, unlike first-degree murder. The State only needs to prove that the defendant's actions were criminally negligent or reckless in order to convict them, with reckless actions being defined as a dangerous disregard for human life resulting in death. The term "reckless disregard" is broad and subjective when considering it. How dangerous do you think the defendant's actions were in causing a death? There are individuals who may not perceive an action as risky in any way. How can a state assess whether one person views the behavior as reckless while another does not? Proving recklessness beyond a reasonable doubt can be challenging due to its subjective nature. The defendant's previous actions can help determine their level of recklessness. If the defendant had previously been accused of the same offense, it would strengthen the State's case.

text1:
[ELI5]Can someone explain the utility of the fifth amendment?
TLDR : The Fifth Amendment protects a citizen from self-incrimination and from arbitrary seizure, as well as assuring a citizen that the government can only take his property for public use through eminent domain. It also assures citizens that the federal government has no authority to create bills of attainder or ex post facto laws. These clauses help ensure fair, objective justice in a world where authorities must make decisions using incomplete information. The Fifth Amendment is an important guarantor of liberty in a large, diverse country where the people in power can’t possibly know each of its citizens on a personal level.
The Fifth Amendment protects a citizen from self-incrimination, arbitrary seizure, and compelled testimony. It also prevents the federal government from levying ex post facto laws, and it prevents the federal government from making laws that apply retroactively to a specific group or individual.
The “self-incrimination” part of the Fifth Amendment is perhaps the most well-known part of it. It guarantees a citizen’s right not to testify against himself or herself in a criminal trial. It is most often used in the context of criminal defense lawyers. Without this right, people could be forced to testify against themselves in court, forcing the government to dig up even the most trivial information and associations.
This right helps keep the legal system fair and free of the possibility of arbitrary charges, arrests, or convictions.

The “ self - incrimination ” part of the Fifth Amendment is probably the most well - famous part of it .It ensures a citizen ’ s right not to testify against himself or herself in a criminal trial . This right aids maintain the legal system fair and free of the prospect of arbitrary charges , arrests , or convictions .
text3: Can someone explain the purpose of the fifth amendment in simple terms? In short: The Fifth Amendment protects citizens from self-incrimination, arbitrary seizure, and ensures that the government can only take property for public use through eminent domain. It also guarantees that the federal government cannot pass laws that punish individuals without a trial or retroactively. These clauses promote fair and impartial justice in a world where officials must make decisions with limited information. The Fifth Amendment is crucial for protecting individual freedoms in a vast and diverse nation where officials cannot personally know every citizen. The Fifth Amendment protects citizens from self-incrimination, arbitrary seizure, and compelled testimony, as well as prohibits the federal government from passing ex post facto laws or retroactively applying laws to individuals or organizations. The Fifth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination is widely known and guarantees the right of a citizen to remain silent in a criminal trial. It is commonly used by criminal defense attorneys. Without this right, individuals could be forced to provide testimony against themselves in court, leading authorities to uncover even the most insignificant details and connections. This right helps ensure that the legal system remains fair and prevents arbitrary charges, arrests, or convictions.

text1:
The basic difference between criminal law and civil law is that criminal law punishes a person’s wrongdoing. In contrast, civil law focuses on resolving disputes among people or groups.
Civil law cases include torts and contract disputes. Tort disputes include personal injury, auto accidents, and product liability cases. Contract disputes include cases involving business, real estate, and family law.
Examples of criminal law include assault, murder, and driving under the influence. The government (state or federal) brings criminal cases. The purpose of criminal law is to prevent people from harming society. Examples include punishing murder, rape, assault, and robbery. For the State of Virginia the rules governing the criminal justice process can be found in the Virginia Code.
Criminal and civil cases usually take place in different courts. Most states have a court system consisting of three levels. However, many states also have specialty courts that handle specific cases.
Q: I have been arrested for a criminal offense in Virginia. What do I need to know?
A: A criminal case begins when you are charged. The person who brings the charges is the prosecutor. The most important thing to know is that the burden of proof is on the State. The Commonwealth has the burden of proving you are guilty beyond a reasonable doubt. That is a very high standard. A jury (or judge if there is no jury) is free to decide the case any way it wants.

Most states have a court system consisting of three levels .However , many states also have specialty judges that handle particular cases . text1: School Psychologists help make sure students are ready to learn. They can perform diagnostic assessments, offer individual counseling, coordinate behavioral and mental health services, consult with parents and teachers, and provide insight into best practices for working with diverse students. School Counselors serve as advocates for students' academic, social, personal, and career development. School Counselors assess students' needs and provide services such as individual counseling and group activities, and help students with educational planning. School Social Workers provide services to students, their families, and the school community to enhance social functioning and to optimize student learning. School Social Workers understand how social, economic, and cultural challenges at home and at school impact students and work to remove barriers to learning.

text1:
Because there should be no bias in the process of deciding cases. In a trial, only the evidence presented and the law of the land is to be applied. If a judge or a jury member were to rely on prejudice or their own opinions of the parties, it would be impossible to determine the facts of the case. Likewise, the judge must make decisions based on the law and the evidence. Thus, all bias is removed by the blindfold, ensuring that the process will be fair and impartial.
​Q: What is the classic symbol of justice and what is the significance of it?
​A: The classic symbol of justice is a woman standing blindfolded and holding a sword in one hand, and a scale in the other. The sword represents the strength needed to take decisions, and the scales symbolize impartiality and fairness.
Q: Are judges equal to the amount of knowledge they gain through education and experience? Is it possible for a judge to be completely knowledgeable about all aspects of the law? If so, how would a judge go about gathering the knowledge and how often would it be required to be updated?
​A: Judges are able to gain an immense amount of knowledge through their formal education and personal experiences. The judiciary is a hierarchical system, and judges gain more responsibility as they climb through the ranks, so the most knowledgeable judges are those at the top of the hierarchy.
However, even a judge at the highest level may not have the best knowledge for every individual case.
text2: Because there should be no prejudice in the process of deciding cases . In a trial , only the proof submitted and the law of the land is to be applied .If a court or a jury member were to depend on bias or their own opinions of the parties , it would be impossible to judge the facts of the case . Likewise , the judge may making decisions based on the law and the proof .Thus , all bias is eliminated by the blindfold , ensuring that the process will be fair and impartial . Q : What is the classic emblem of justice and what is the importance of it ?A : The classic symbol of justice is a lady standing blindfolded and holding a blade in one hand , and a scale in the other . The sword depicts the strength needed to take choices , and the scales symbolize impartiality and fairness .Q : Are courts equal to the quantity of expertise they acquire through education and experience ? Is it possible for a court to be utterly knowledgeable about all aspects of the law ?If so , how might a court go about gathering the knowledge and how often would it be required to be revised ? A : Judges are able to obtain an immense amount of expertise through their formal education and personal experiences .The judiciary is a hierarchical structure , and judges gain more responsibility as they rise through the ranks , so the most knowledgeable judges are those at the highest of the hierarchy . However , even a court at the highest level may not have the best knowledge for every individual case .
text3: Prejudice should not play a role in the decision-making process for cases. During a trial, only evidence and the legal system should be considered. If a court or jury member relies on bias or personal opinions of the parties, it would hinder their ability to assess the facts of the case. Similarly, the judge will base decisions on legal principles and evidence, ensuring fairness and impartiality by removing all bias through the blindfold. What symbol represents justice and why is it significant? What symbol is emblematic of justice and what is its importance? The traditional representation of justice is a blindfolded woman holding a sword and scales. Does the level of education and experience acquired by courts equate to their fairness and impartiality? Can a court have complete knowledge of every aspect of the law? How would a court gather necessary knowledge and how frequently would it need to be updated? What symbol is emblematic of justice and why is it important? Judges acquire extensive knowledge and expertise through their formal education and personal experiences, with the most knowledgeable judges typically found at the top of the judicial hierarchy. Nevertheless, even the highest court may not possess the most comprehensive knowledge for each specific case.

text1:
While the vast majority of arrests are not initiated with force, some are. Such is the case for a majority of your questions. Yes, there are legal limits to force, and charging one with resisting to overcome those limits is a violation of those legal limits.
Look, police train that everyone and I mean everyone will resist arrest. Why? Because the person they arrested didn’t do anything illegal, and it is a matter of pride that they find the "smoking gun" that is enough to book and jail someone. This is because they, like all citizens of the country, believe in the rule of law and want to see it upheld. I am going to talk about this specifically later, but because there is such a high level of force for resisting, there is a lot of constitutional law on this. It doesn’t matter what some crazy officer believes in, they must follow the law.
As far as “pain” causing an involuntary muscle response, that is incorrect. For starters, pain is a subjective experience and must be identified by the individual experiencing it. For instance, a tight pair of jeans on a young woman, even if snug may not be painful. The same tight pair of jeans on a man may be painful. On the other hand, a wide tooth comb pulled through wet hair is not painful on me, but may be painful for you. As for an “involuntary muscle response,” that is also incorrect.
text2: While the vast bulk of arrests are not initiated with force , some are . Such is the case for a majority of your questions .Yes , there are legal limits to force , and accusing one with resisting to overcome those limitation is a violation of those legal limits . Look , cops train that everyone and I mean everyone will resist arrest .Why ? Because the person they arrested didn ’ t do anything unlawful , and it is a matter of pride that they discover the " smoking gun " that is enough to book and jail anyone .This is because they , like all citizens of the nation , think in the rule of law and want to see it enforced . I am going to talk about this specifically later , but because there is such a high degree of force for resisting , there is a plenty of constitutional law on this .It doesn ’ t matter what some crazy policeman believes in , they must follow the law . As far as “ pain ” causing an involuntary muscle response , that is incorrect .For starters , pain is a subjective feeling and must be identified by the person feeling it . For instance , a tight pair of jeans on a young woman , even if snug may not be painful .The same tight pair of jeans on a man may be painful . On the other hand , a broad tooth comb pulled through wet hair is not unpleasant on me , but might be painful for you .As for an “ involuntary muscle response , ” that is also wrong .
text3: Although most arrests do not involve the use of force, there are some that do. Most of your questions fall into this category, where there are legal boundaries for the use of force and falsely accusing someone of resisting violates those boundaries. Police officers are trained to treat everyone equally. Why will everyone resist arrest? People resist arrest because they believe in the rule of law and want to ensure it is upheld, especially when they feel they have not committed any wrongdoing. I will address this topic in more detail later, but there is a significant amount of constitutional law regarding the use of force when resisting arrest. It is essential for law enforcement officers to adhere to the law, regardless of their personal beliefs. The idea that pain can cause an involuntary muscle response is inaccurate. Firstly, pain is a personal experience that must be recognized by the individual experiencing it. A young woman may find a tight pair of jeans comfortable, while a man may find the same pair painful. Contrary to that, using a wide-tooth comb on wet hair may not be uncomfortable for me, but it could be painful for you. Additionally, the concept of an "involuntary muscle response" is also incorrect.

text1:
For any given alcoholic, how long it takes to detox safely depends on many factors. If someone has been drinking at high levels for a long time, they may need to go through a medical detox, where they can be monitored and assisted with mild medication if needed to help alleviate symptoms like tremors and vomiting.
For those who can detox at home, it can take days for the toxins to clear their body, and for withdrawal symptoms to ease. Many alcoholics relapse, though, when detoxing. However, most alcoholics who relapse start drinking again after a couple days or weeks. But an alcoholic who has been arrested may not have alcohol available and might try to detox at home (which is dangerous) or just stop all together. There are some sober individuals who successfully recover, but that's not the norm. Even if you don't drink at all, and are in a safe place, withdrawing from alcohol can kill you.
Most people who have been drinking heavily and are trying to quit, are successful, at least at first. But for most, alcohol dependence isn't just a matter of drinking. You have to not drink too, which for most alcoholics is very difficult. If you're not sure, you can call me or other resources, and we can help you decide what to do.
text2: For any given alcoholic , how long it takes to detox safely depends on numerous variables . If someone has been drank at high levels for a long time , they may need to run through a medical detox , where they can be monitored and assisted with mild medication if needed to assist ease symptoms like tremors and vomiting .For those who can detox at home , it can take days for the toxins to clear their body , and for withdrawal symptoms to ease . Many alcoholics relapse , though , when detoxing .However , most alcoholics who relapse start drunk again after a couple weeks or months . But an alcoholic who has been arrested may not have drinking available and might try to detox at home ( which is dangerous ) or just stop all together .There are some sober individuals who successfully recover , but that ' s not the norm . Even if you don ' t drink at all , and are in a safe spot , withdrawing from drink can kill you .Most people who have been drank heavily and are trying to quit , are successful , at least at first . But for most , alcohol dependence isn ' t just a matter of alcohol .You have to not alcohol too , which for most alcoholics is very difficult . If you ' re not certain , you can call me or other resources , and we can help you determine what to do .
text3: The length of time needed for a safe detox from alcohol varies depending on several factors for each individual. Individuals who have been consuming alcohol heavily for an extended period may require medical detox to be monitored and receive mild medication to alleviate symptoms such as tremors and vomiting. For those detoxing at home, it may take several days for the toxins to leave their system and for withdrawal symptoms to improve. Most alcoholics who relapse end up drinking again within a few weeks or months. However, an alcoholic who has been arrested may not have access to alcohol and may attempt to detox at home or quit drinking altogether, which can be risky. There are a few individuals who are able to recover successfully, but it is not common. Abstaining from alcohol, even in a safe environment, can be life-threatening. Many heavy drinkers who attempt to quit are initially successful. For many alcoholics, quitting alcohol is not just about giving up alcohol - it also involves avoiding alcohol, which is a challenging task for most. If you're unsure, feel free to reach out to me or other sources for assistance in figuring out the next steps.

text1: Refusing to comply with a subpoena can carry very serious consequences, so it’s important that you speak with a lawyer first before disobeying. I will give you a short explanation here, but I recommend contacting a lawyer for more information. What you want to find out is whether the subpoena is authorized, what consequences may result from not complying, what potential defenses to a claim of contempt you have and how long a case is likely to last. As you probably know, subpoenas can be either “compulsory” or “permissive.” In other words, you may have a good legal argument that you are under no legal obligation to comply. However, because the person issuing the subpoena is likely to respond to your resistance by claiming that you are in “contempt” of the court and demanding that you be cited, jailed or otherwise punished, it’s probably not a good idea to just refuse to turn over the documents and wait to see what happens. If you have any questions or would like to know more about the specific circumstances of your situation, please feel free to contact me at wwh@lawhelpinteractive.org.
text2: Refusing to compliance with a subpoena can carry very severe consequences , so it ’ s important that you talk with a lawyer first before disobeying . I will giving you a brief explanation here , but I recommend contacting a lawyer for more information .What you want to find out is whether the subpoena is approved , what consequences may come from not complying , what prospective defenses to a claim of contempt you have and how long a case is likely to last . As you perhaps know , subpoenas can be either “ compulsory ” or “ permissive . ” In other words , you may have a good legal argument that you are under no legal duty to compliance .However , because the person issuing the subpoena is likely to respond to your resistance by claiming that you are in “ contempt ” of the court and requesting that you be cited , arrested or otherwise punished , it ’ s probably not a better idea to just refuse to turn over the documents and wait to see what happens . If you have any questions or would like to know more about the specific circumstances of your situation , please feel free to contact me at wwh @ lawhelpinteractive . org .
text3: It is crucial to consult with a lawyer before disobeying a subpoena, as there can be serious repercussions for noncompliance. I will provide a brief explanation here, but I suggest reaching out to a lawyer for further details. It is important to determine if the subpoena is valid, understand the potential consequences of noncompliance, identify possible defenses against a contempt claim, and estimate the duration of the case. Subpoenas can be categorized as either mandatory or optional. Put simply, you might have a strong legal case that you are not obligated to comply. It is not advisable to simply refuse to comply with a subpoena, as this could result in being accused of contempt of court and facing potential punishment. If you need more information or have any inquiries about your particular situation, please don't hesitate to reach out to me at wwh @ lawhelpinteractive. If you have any questions or need further information about your specific situation, feel free to contact me at wwh @ lawhelpinteractive.

text1:
The criminals manage to be where the mass surveillance can’t see them. At least, that’s what I argue in my latest book, Stealing the Network: How to Own the Box. This book has 10 stories of hackers at work, with a team of professional writers and I contributing scenarios. In my story, I reveal the infrastructure of organized cybercrime, which (like organized crime in the real world) lives in the gaps and seams of legitimate systems.
How does the criminal element manage to evade detection from law enforcement and the corporate security community? Here are some of the approaches I suggest in my scenario:
Organizationally, the cybercrime family (or organization) lives off the grid. Like real-life organized crime, the hackers hire ordinary people to do mundane, under-the-radar work.
Locally, criminals hide behind the “firewall farms” (data centers that house large corporate firewalls), for example, 7 Wonders Media.
Geographically, the criminals hide in foreign countries that make it difficult for law enforcement to operate.
Personally, criminals use disposable phones and devices, and evade “systematic” surveillance by constantly changing their tactics.
Technologically, criminals leave breadcrumbs that mislead security personnel about who is attacking them.
Criminals use legitimate systems in ways they weren’t designed for. An example would be using ICANN services (such as domain lookups) to determine whether a company is using anti-fraud or anti-DDOS security tools.

At least , that ’ s what I say in my current book , Stealing the Network : How to Own the Box .This book has 10 stories of hackers at work , with a team of career writers and I contributing situations . Here are some of the strategies I propose in my scenario : Organizationally , the cybercrime family ( or organization ) lives off the grid .Like real - life organized criminals , the hackers hire normal people to do mundane , under - the - radar work . Locally , criminals hide behind the “ firewall farms ” ( computer centers that store large corporate firewalls ) , for example , 7 Wonders Media .Geographically , the criminals hide in foreign countries that give it difficult for law enforcement to operate . Personally , criminals use disposable phones and devices , and evade “ systematic ” surveillance by frequently altering their strategies .Technologically , criminals leave breadcrumbs that mislead safety officers about who is attacking them . Criminals use legitimate systems in ways they weren ’ t designed for .An example would be employing ICANN services ( such as domain lookups ) to judge whether a corporation is employing anti - cheating or anti - DDOS security tools .
text3: The criminals are able to evade detection by the mass monitoring system. In my latest book, Stealing the Network: How to Own the Box, I share 10 stories of hackers in action, collaborating with a team of professional writers. I expose the inner workings of organized cybercrime, which thrives within the loopholes of legitimate systems, similar to real-world organized crime. How do criminals avoid being detected by law enforcement and corporate security? These are the tactics I suggest in my scenario. The cybercrime group operates off the grid and, like real-world criminals, they hire regular individuals for low-profile tasks. Criminals use firewall farms like 7 Wonders Media to hide locally, and they also operate in foreign countries to make it challenging for law enforcement to track them down. Criminals use disposable phones and devices to avoid being detected by surveillance systems, and they frequently change their tactics to mislead security officers. Criminals exploit legitimate systems for their own purposes, such as using ICANN services to assess a company's security measures.

text1:
One of the main reasons for copyright is that the creator gets credit for the work (like the Berne Convention 14 years after death). With copyright, the creator will get his/her works performed or published and recognized. The "lost profits" might be substituted by awarding royalties to the heirs (e.g., John Steinbeck's Estate). Public domain means that everyone gets the same rights to use the material as the creator: both the right to copy and to modify.
I have gone through your website and found that you have given many examples about your work and so on but I don't know from where you are getting all the examples or how you are getting the ideas and also give a link of that particular example.
Sir, you are saying that, it is more important to give credit to the author. My question is, is it a must to give credit to the author? Can I write a book by stealing the ideas of the authors?
Re the example and ideas: some are mine, some are from friends, some from colleagues or acquaintances, and many from the various software I use: my laptop, my Iphone, my car, my cell phone, my bank, my grocery store, etc.
Re copyright and plagiarism, it would be very difficult to tell someone not to plagiarize a book idea. However, many publishing houses have plagiarism software that they use to check whether a book is close to another one.

text3: Copyright is important because it ensures that the creator is credited for their work, even after their death, as seen in the Berne Convention. Copyright allows creators to have their work performed or published and acknowledged, with potential profits being replaced by royalties for their heirs. Copyright ensures that creators are recognized for their work and allows their heirs to receive royalties. John Steinbeck's heirs are still able to receive royalties from his work. Public domain grants equal rights to all individuals to utilize content, including the ability to copy and alter it. Is it necessary to give credit to the writer, as you are suggesting, sir? Is it acceptable for me to plagiarize other writers' ideas in order to create a book? I draw inspiration and ideas from a variety of sources, including my own experiences, colleagues, acquaintances, and the technology I use in my daily life. It is challenging to prevent someone from plagiarizing a book idea when considering copyright and plagiarism. Numerous publishing companies utilize plagiarism detection software to determine if a book closely resembles another one.

text1:
It depends on what you mean by "sometimes."  A criminal defendant is presumed innocent of the charges brought against them.  This means the defense attorney is not at liberty to do anything except provide a vigorous defense.  In the context of a plea bargain, where the government offers the defendant certain leniency in exchange for a guilty plea, it is the attorney's job to assess the risks of going to trial and make sure that the defendant understands the risks of the various pleas offered.
This is also important in determining whether to accept a "deal" the prosecutor offers, rather than take the case to trial.  In many jurisdictions, the prosecutor may only offer a single plea bargain deal that is not acceptable to the defendant.  A lawyer's job is to assess the likelihood of success at trial and advise the defendant on the risks and benefits of various options.
text2: It depends on what you mean by " sometimes . " A criminal defendant is presumed innocent of the allegations raised against them .This implies the defense attorney is not at freedom to do anything except provide a vigorous defense . In the context of a plea bargain , where the government offers the defendant specific leniency in exchange for a guilty plea , it is the prosecutor ' s task to analyze the dangers of going to trial and get sure that the defendant knows the dangers of the various pleas given .This is also important in identifying whether to accept a " offer " the prosecutor offers , rather than taking the case to trial . In many jurisdictions , the prosecutor could only accept a single plea bargain deal that is not acceptable to the defendant .A attorney ' s role is to examine the probability of success at court and advise the defendant on the dangers and advantages of several choices .
text3: The meaning of "sometimes" varies. A defense attorney must provide a strong defense for a criminal defendant who is presumed innocent. When considering a plea bargain, the prosecutor must assess the risks of going to trial and ensure the defendant understands the consequences of different plea options before deciding whether to accept the prosecutor's offer or proceed to trial. In some places, the prosecutor may offer only one plea deal that the defendant may not agree with. An attorney's responsibility is to evaluate the likelihood of success in court and inform the defendant about the risks and benefits of various options.

text1:
Because we can't get money for professional photographers.
Courtroom artists are independent contractors who sit in courtrooms or other venues and "sketch" what they see, sometimes in real time, for news organizations to print or broadcast. (Courts and courthouses don't usually supply paper and pens.) Courtroom artists are the reporters' tools for recording what is happening in the legal proceedings and reporting them back to their news organization, along with stories written by the reporters. We are the only witnesses in a courtroom who are allowed to move freely about and actually sketch what is going on. We're here to inform you about what's going on, because journalists rely on us to do so. We are the only ones on the scene. Also, sometimes, we may not be in the courtrooms, but are at news conferences or press briefings which they can't attend.
Do courtroom artists have to attend only trials and pretrial hearings? Do we draw people, scenes, maps, diagrams and blueprints, too?
Yes! We do our best to get to the courtroom in time for court so we can get set up to work. Often, we may attend pretrial hearings, depositions, lawyers' conferences and other "legal doings." Courtroom artists are there to tell you what's happening as best we can. Courtroom artists usually don't know anything more than what is presented at the court proceedings.

We ' re here to remind you about what ' s going on , because journalists rely on us to do so .We are the only ones on the scene . " Courtroom artists are there to remind you what ' s happening as best we can .Courtroom artists often don ' t know anything more than what is presented at the court proceedings .

Paper and pens are not typically provided in courts or courthouses. Courtroom artists are essential for newspapers to visually document legal proceedings, working alongside reporters who write articles. Courtroom artists have the unique ability to freely move around and visually capture the events taking place in the courtroom. We are here to provide visual documentation of legal proceedings for journalists who depend on us. are the sole individuals present. We also cover media conferences or briefings that they are unable to attend. Courtroom artists are required to attend trials and pretrial hearings exclusively. Are we also responsible for sketching people, scenes, maps, diagrams, and blueprints? Affirmative! We make sure to arrive at the courtroom on time for trials in order to set up and start working. Additionally, we may also attend pretrial hearings, depositions, lawyers' conferences, and other legal events. Courtroom artists are responsible for sketching people, scenes, maps, diagrams, and blueprints. Courtroom artists are present to visually document legal proceedings to the best of their ability, even if they may not have additional information beyond what is presented in court.

text1:
Alford pleas were made famous in the 1997 movie “Primal Fear” starring Richard Gere. Gere played an attorney who helps a sociopathic killer (Edward Norton) get off by going the Alford route, whereby the defendant says he is guilty while maintaining his innocence. The doctrine was developed in the 1976 United States Supreme Court case of North Carolina v. Alford.
An Alford plea is used when there is insufficient evidence to prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt, but the defendant, after consultation with his attorney, still wants to resolve his case. This occurs most often in the context of a negotiated plea, which is an agreement between the defense attorney and the prosecutor as to the charge or charges to be filed and the punishment to be recommended. In an Alford plea, the defendant pleads guilty to one or more charges and the prosecutor agrees to drop other charges. The Alford plea is a way to save face for the defendant who wants to keep his or her record clean but does not believe he is guilty of all charges.
In the context of a trial, an Alford plea is more controversial. The Supreme Court has determined that a defendant has the right to plead guilty while maintaining his innocence. But the court has also determined that the defendant must have actually entered into the plea. Judges often refer to this as a knowing, intelligent and voluntary plea.
text2: Alford pleas were made famous in the 1997 movie “ Primal Fear ” starring Richard Gere . Gere played an lawyer who assists a sociopathic murderer ( Edward Norton ) get off by going the Alford route , whereby the defendant believes he is innocent while maintaining his innocence .The doctrine was developed in the 1976 United States Supreme Court decision of North Carolina v . Alford . An Alford pleading is utilized when there is insufficient proof to prove innocence beyond a rational doubt , but the defendant , after consultation with his lawyer , still wants to resolution his case .This occurs most usually in the context of a negotiated plea , which is an agreement between the defense attorney and the prosecutor as to the charge or charges to be filed and the penalty to be recommended . In an Alford pleading , the defendant pleads guilty to one or more charges and the prosecutor agrees to drop other accusations .The Alford pleading is a way to save face for the defendant who wishes to keep his or her record clean but does not believe he is innocent of all charges . In the context of a prosecution , an Alford pleading is more controversial .The Supreme Court has decided that a defendant has the right to plead guilty while maintaining his innocence . But the court has also determined that the defendant must have actually entered into the plea .Judges often refer to this as a knowing , efficient and voluntary plea .
text3: Alford pleas gained popularity through their portrayal in the 1997 film "Primal Fear" featuring Richard Gere. In "Primal Fear," Richard Gere portrayed a lawyer who helps a sociopathic murderer, played by Edward Norton, use the Alford plea to maintain innocence while accepting guilt. The Alford plea gained attention through its depiction in the movie "Primal Fear" starring Richard Gere. An Alford plea is used when there isn't enough evidence to prove innocence beyond a reasonable doubt, but the defendant, with advice from their lawyer, still wants to resolve their case. This typically happens in the context of a negotiated plea deal between the defense attorney and prosecutor regarding charges and penalties. In an Alford plea, the defendant admits guilt to certain charges while the prosecutor agrees to dismiss other allegations. Alford pleas allow defendants to maintain their innocence while admitting guilt to certain charges in order to avoid a criminal conviction. An Alford plea is considered controversial in legal proceedings, as it allows a defendant to plead guilty while still asserting their innocence, a right upheld by the Supreme Court. Judges require that the defendant entered the plea knowingly, voluntarily, and efficiently.

text1:
A woman is less likely to lie about being raped than a man is to lie about his innocence when accused of rape.
“ Rape shield laws  are laws in various U.S. jurisdictions which generally restrict the admissibility of evidence concerning the sexual history or character of a complainant of sexual assault. The rationale for such laws is the concern that the introduction of irrelevant sexual history evidence can discourage rape victims from reporting, appearing in court, or testifying. Another rationale is that introduction of irrelevant sexual history evidence may be prejudicial, distracting the fact-finder’s attention away from the question of whether the defendant committed the charged offense, to the question of the complainant’s sexual history or reputation.”
The above quote from Wikipedia puts it succinctly. A victim of rape may well be more reluctant to report the crime, or testify in court if they know their character will be sullied by the public. They might not do either if they know it’s futile anyway and the chance of winning is little. Of course, that’s assuming it’s even a rape. We’re assuming the victim is telling the truth. If it’s not, then they might have expected to be punished for being a liar. In other words, it doesn’t really matter to a rapist whether they will be accused of rape, or accused of rape, and it be impossible to prove. Their interests in not being accused will be about the same as a non-rapist who is innocent.

S . jurisdictions which generally restrict the admissibility of evidence involving the sexual history or character of a complainant of sex assault .The rationale for such laws is the concern that the introduction of irrelevant sexual history evidence can discourage rape survivors from reporting , appearing in court , or testifying . Another rationale is that addition of irrelevant sexual history evidence may be prejudicial , distracting the fact - finder ’ s attention away from the question of whether the defendant committed the accused offense , to the question of the complainant ’ s sexual history or reputation . ” The above quote from Wikipedia gives it succinctly .A victim of rape might well be more reluctant to report the crime , or testify in court if they realize their character will be sullied by the public . They might not do either if they realize it ’ s futile anyway and the hope of winning is little .Of course , that ’ s assuming it ’ s even a rape . We ’ re assuming the victim is told the truth .If it ’ s not , then they may have expected to be punished for being a liar . In other words , it doesn ’ t truly matter to a rapist whether they will be convicted of rape , or accused of rape , and it be impossible to prove .Their interests in not being accused will be about the same as a non - rapist who is innocent .

Laws in different states safeguard the confidentiality of rape victims. States typically limit the use of evidence related to a sexual assault victim's past in court to protect survivors from feeling discouraged to report or testify. Introducing irrelevant sexual history evidence could divert attention from determining the defendant's guilt to focusing on the complainant's past sexual activities or reputation. The quote from Wikipedia summarizes it concisely. A rape victim may hesitate to report the crime or testify in court if they fear their reputation will be tarnished. If they believe there is little chance of winning and it may be pointless, they may choose not to report the crime, especially if they are unsure if it even qualifies as rape. We are operating under the assumption that the victim is being honest. If the victim is not being truthful, they may have anticipated facing consequences for their dishonesty. Essentially, rapists are not concerned about the possibility of being convicted or accused of rape if it cannot be proven, similar to innocent individuals who are not rapists.

First off, they must live in Texas where I have been told is a good place to live. In Texas the Republicans are in charge, so they get to pick the demographics for their district lines. They picked them such that districts have either a large minority population or a small one.
There is a big difference in voter turnout between those who live in districts with a large minority population and those who live in districts with a small minority population. There is very little turnover in the latter. Voter ID requirements disproportionately suppress the voter turnout of minority voters. They also prohibit the informal process of gathering information from neighbors, churches and civic clubs, which is how low income people vote. Because the government won’t collect data on the effects of voter ID laws on a county or state level, no one knows the effects of the law.
I was in Texas working with voter turnout for a student group, and it’s kind of shocking how many people are going to the trouble of getting a government ID, which requires a lot more effort than just saying I am who I say I am. I met one guy who was 88 years old. He has been voting in person since 1956. Now he would need a new ID. This law is affecting old people and low income people.
On this blog I advocate the laissez-faire policy of letting free people do what they want, not government imposed solutions to problems, even problems created by the government.

text1: There are many types of procedures in place to ensure that police obtain evidence legally and without violating an individual's constitutional rights.  For instance, police must always obtain a search warrant or a consent to search before they search a home, automobile, or other property.  An illegally obtained piece of evidence is not admissible at trial, which could prevent a police officer from obtaining an arrest or conviction against the individual.  In some cases, police will obtain evidence illegally, then obtain additional evidence in order to use the illegal evidence in court.  For instance, police may discover evidence of a crime in plain sight during a search, and may try to argue that they should have entered the home in order to search for that evidence.  If the court determines that this evidence would be admissible under this argument, then they can try to exclude the illegal evidence in the case, and use the evidence that would be admissible in its place.  If the court cannot exclude the illegal evidence in the case, then the police will not be able to use it, and they will have to try to rely on the new, legal evidence that they obtained during the search.  While the police may try to find legal ways to obtain evidence in a way that is different from how they found the original evidence, police are usually unable to do this.
text2: There are many kinds of practices in place to ensure that police obtain evidence legally and without violating an individual ' s constitutional rights . For instance , authorities must always obtain a search warrant or a consent to search before they search a home , automobile , or other land .An illegally received item of evidence is not admissible at trial , which could prohibit a police officer from securing an arrest or conviction against the person . In some cases , authorities will acquire testimony illegally , then obtain additional evidence in order to use the illegal proof in court .For instance , authorities might discover proof of a crime in plain sight during a search , and may try to argue that they should have entered the home in order to search for that evidence . If the court determines that this evidence would be admissible under this argument , then they can try to eliminate the illegal proof in the case , and use the proof that would be admissible in its place .If the court cannot exclude the illegal proof in the case , then the authorities will not be able to use it , and they will have to try to depend on the new , legal information that they obtained during the search . While the authorities might try to find legal methods to obtain evidence in a way that is distinct from how they obtained the original proof , authorities are typically cannot to do this .
text3: Various methods are used to make sure that law enforcement acquires evidence in a lawful manner and without infringing on a person's constitutional rights. Law enforcement must always have permission to search a home, car, or other property, either through a search warrant or consent. If evidence is obtained illegally, it cannot be used in court, potentially hindering law enforcement's ability to make an arrest or secure a conviction. Sometimes, law enforcement may illegally obtain testimony and then gather more evidence to use the illegally obtained proof in court, such as finding evidence of a crime in plain sight during a search and arguing they had the right to enter the home to search for it. If the court decides that the evidence can be used based on that argument, they may exclude the illegally obtained evidence and use admissible evidence instead. If the court does not exclude the illegally obtained evidence, law enforcement will have to rely on the new, legally obtained information gathered during the search. Law enforcement often attempts to obtain evidence through legal means that are different from how they initially acquired it, but they are usually unable to do so.

text1:
The justice system is a marathon not a sprint. Cases take time for the discovery process to be conducted. They require investigation of evidence, locating witnesses, etc. Courts are overburdened with cases and are reluctant to grant urgent relief. Due process requires that all litigants be given an opportunity to have their day in court.
Q: My spouse will not let me see my children. What can I do?
A: Seek immediate assistance from a family lawyer who will advise you of your options. In some cases the court can issue orders compelling the other party to allow the children to be returned and supervised by the court in a neutral environment. There are a variety of court orders that can assist in resolving the issues.
Q: What is the difference between a divorce and a separation?
A: In a divorce the parties are required to attend a mandatory Information Program and to complete a financial disclosure form. The Court uses the information provided by the parties to assess their financial situations. Separation is used to document the break up of a marriage. It does not require any formal attendance at an Information Program, but can be a useful interim step prior to applying for a divorce.
Q: What if the other parent or spouse takes the children?
A: This is the most difficult situation to deal with, particularly if the other parent or spouse has removed the children from the province. There are a number of steps that can be taken by a qualified lawyer to deal with these circumstances.

text1:
people with codependency have difficulty recognizing their own needs and emotions, let alone being able to articulate them. Also, they have a hard time recognizing what other people need, what they feel, or even how they might go about getting those needs met. They are extremely focused on what everyone else needs and wants. They live by the motto “Your needs, wants, and feelings are my first priority.” These people tend to have poor boundaries and therefore, can have difficulty differentiating between what’s going on with other people and what’s going on in their own lives. Codependency can be at play in relationships, families, or workplaces and can result in things like enabling, self-sacrifice, tolerance, and people-pleasing, among other things. When codependency is so strong that it impacts one’s ability to function effectively, it can become a disorder.
Q: what’s the difference between jealousy and envy?
A: jealousy is about not wanting to lose the love, affection, or attention of the one you love. It may be about the future of a relationship, but it also could be about the past (even if that past has long passed) in that the one who is jealous may be concerned about not having lost the loved one in the past and about not risking the loss of that person in the future. When people are experiencing jealousy, they may experience a wide variety of physical and emotional reactions (which will be unique to them).

text3: Individuals struggling with codependency struggle to identify their own desires and feelings, making it challenging for them to express them. Additionally, they find it difficult to understand the needs, emotions, and methods of others in fulfilling those needs. They are highly attentive to the needs and desires of others. They prioritize the needs, wants, and feelings of others above their own. Individuals with codependency struggle to set boundaries and often have trouble distinguishing between the emotions and needs of others and their own personal experiences. This behavior can manifest in various relationships and settings, leading to actions such as enabling, self-sacrifice, tolerance, and people-pleasing. Codependency can become a disease when it significantly impairs one's ability to function effectively. Jealousy stems from a fear of losing the love, affection, or attention of a loved one, whether in the past or potentially in the future. Jealousy can trigger a range of physical and emotional responses that are specific to each individual.

Multiple life sentences are actually far more appropriate than the alternative which is the death penalty. For one thing, they are far less expensive than the death penalty, which must be carried out by lethal injection and which also includes the fact that inmates are frequently taken out of their cells to the execution room only to be placed back in their cells when it is determined that it cannot be completed for one reason or another.
The issue is often portrayed as good versus bad or as a true believer versus a bad person who doesn’t believe anything. Unfortunately, this is not true. Most of the time, the real conflict is between true believers and the legal system.
There is a strong body of thought, as exemplified by Christian and Judaic law, which suggests that if someone is found guilty of an egregious sin, then there is no possibility of redemption or forgiveness. The law will not allow for it and there is no recourse to plead for mercy in that regard.
The problem here is that it takes into account only a single deed that took place over a span of time. Of course, there are cases in which there is a single act of extreme violence against the law, and they should be sentenced accordingly. For example, a judge can sentence a single killer to a life sentence, and the law will generally support that.

text1: The most important first step after an arrest is contacting an attorney immediately. Sometimes, that happens before the person is even booked into jail. If a person is arrested on a search warrant, or a search warrant is applied for, the first thing that needs to happen is the attorney needs to talk to the police officer and the judge on the record to say whether the attorney has standing to request a suppression hearing. If they have standing, the court should set a date for that to occur and a suppression hearing is the only way to address whether or not that evidence should be thrown out.
text2: The most important first step after an arrest is contacting an lawyer immediately . If they have standing , the court should put a date for that to occur and a suppression hearing is the only way to address whether or not that evidence should be thrown out .
text3: It is crucial to reach out to a lawyer right away after being arrested. In some cases, this occurs prior to the individual being processed into the jail. When someone is arrested on a search warrant, the attorney should immediately speak with the police officer and judge to determine if they have the right to request a suppression hearing. If the individual has legal standing, the court must schedule a suppression hearing to determine if the evidence should be excluded.

text1:
The vast majority of illegal drug busts are minor, and generally result in a Class B misdemeanor charge. If an individual is convicted of a Class B misdemeanor, he or she faces a fine of up to $2,000 and possible jail time.
In misdemeanor drug cases, the common rule of thumb is that if you have less than two ounces of marijuana, a certain number of grams of a different substance, or a small amount of methamphetamine, you will likely be charged with a Class B misdemeanor. However, sometimes people are charged with more serious felonies for drug offenses even if they did not have very much illegal drug substance on their person.
Depending on what the evidence shows, a drug bust case can be handled in a lot of different ways. If, for example, an individual is found with only a small amount of marijuana in a vehicle, but there is no evidence that he or she was actively using the substance, it may be possible to negotiate a resolution that avoids a conviction. Sometimes the state might agree to drop the criminal charge if the defendant enters into an alcohol/drug education program or completes some community service. That way, the defendant’s criminal record does not show a conviction.

However , sometimes people are charged with more serious felonies for drug offenses even if they did not have very much illegal drug substance on their person .Depending on what the proof indicates , a marijuana bust case can be treated in a lot of different ways . If , for example , an individual is found with only a small amount of marijuana in a vehicle , but there is no evidence that he or she was aggressively using the substance , it could be possible to obtain a resolution that avoids a conviction .Sometimes the state would decide to drop the criminal charge if the defendant enters into an alcohol / drug school facility or completes some community service . That way , the defendant ’ s criminal history does not show a conviction .

Typically, possessing a small amount of marijuana, a specific quantity of another drug, or a small amount of methamphetamine will likely result in a Class B misdemeanor charge. In some cases, individuals may face felony charges for drug offenses despite having a small amount of illegal substances, and the outcome of a marijuana bust case can vary based on the evidence presented. In certain situations, it may be possible to reach a resolution that avoids a conviction if someone is found with a small amount of marijuana in their vehicle without evidence of aggressive use. The state may choose to dismiss the charge if the defendant enrolls in a substance abuse program or fulfills community service requirements. This prevents the defendant from having a conviction on their criminal record.

"It seems that these steps [to clamp down on hacking, encryption and espionage] have been coordinated and can be considered as a global plan of action," says Rid. "It's a coordinated international campaign. We see it in all these countries around the world taking action at the same time against all these different things."
A: How much power the US, UK and the other countries in the Five Eyes surveillance alliance hold over the internet is overstated, according to a French government official speaking on condition of anonymity.
"The Five Eyes are certainly making decisions with major impacts on global services. But one cannot say that they're going to destroy the internet, or that they're going to block it," the official says.
Asked about the French decision to force VPN providers to register, the official said the French "looked first at who they have to collaborate with." If the government had to identify the VPN providers, they reasoned that it made more sense to go through the US companies that provide services to French users instead of the foreign VPN providers.

In its strictest legal sense, a natural, individual human being, and not a corporation; in its generic sense, it includes all rational and intelligent beings. This is the most universal definition. It includes the whole human family, all men and women, good or bad, of whatever race or color. In another sense, the term is limited to those who are of sound mind, and have not been dispossessed of the rights of men, so as to be incapable of representing themselves in their own persons, or defending their rights and interests. This definition excludes infants, insane persons, and criminals convicted of treason or felony in some states. In some of the American states, idiots, insane, and convicts under sentence of imprisonment for crime, are not considered to be persons. Such persons are not entitled to the rights and privileges of a citizen, but in such states they are not to be deprived of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law. (outragedusman)
Q: Blacks law dictionary: Person
A: The term has no special legal meaning in the 1st Amend. It includes "all those who are subjects or citizens of the United States and all aliens, whether friendly, neutral, or enemy, who are within the dominion of the United States." United States v. Verdugo-Urquidez, 494 U.S. 259, 265, 108 L. Ed.
